House of Zhao

The forebears of the Zhao clan shared a common ancestor with Qin. The line reached Zhong Yan, who served as Emperor Da Wu's charioteer. In later generations, Feilian had two sons. He named one son Elai, who served King Zhou but was killed by the Zhou. His descendants became the Qin clan. Elai's younger brother was named Jisheng. His descendants became the Zhao clan.
2
å­£å‹ç”Ÿå­Ÿå¢ã€‚ å­Ÿå¢å¹¸æ–¼å‘¨æˆç‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå®…çš‹ç‹¼ã€‚ çš‹ç‹¼ç”Ÿè¡¡çˆ¶ï¼Œè¡¡çˆ¶ç”Ÿé€ çˆ¶ã€‚ é€ çˆ¶å¹¸æ–¼å‘¨ç¹†ç‹ã€‚ é€ çˆ¶å–é©¥ä¹‹ä¹˜åŒ¹ï¼Œèˆ‡æ¡ƒæ—ç›œé©ªã€é©Šé¨®ã€ç¶ è€³ï¼Œç»ä¹‹ç¹†ç‹ã€‚ ç¹†ç‹ä½¿é€ çˆ¶å¾¡ï¼Œè¥¿å·¡ç‹©ï¼Œè¦‹è¥¿ç‹æ¯ï¼Œæ¨‚ä¹‹å¿˜æ­¸ã€‚ è€Œå¾åƒç‹åï¼Œç¹†ç‹æ—¥é¦³åƒé‡Œé¦¬ï¼Œæ”»å¾åƒç‹ï¼Œå¤§ç ´ä¹‹ã€‚ ä¹ƒè³œé€ çˆ¶ä»¥è¶™åŸï¼Œç”±æ­¤ç‚ºè¶™æ°ã€‚
Jisheng begat Mengzeng. Mengzeng found favor with King Cheng of Zhou and became known as Zhaigaolang. Gaolang begat Hengfu, who begat Zaofu. Zaofu found favor with King Mu of Zhou. Zaofu acquired Ji's chariot team, along with the stolen horses Lilu, Hualiu, and Lver from Taolin, and presented them all to King Mu. King Mu had Zaofu drive his chariot on a western tour. They met the Queen Mother of the West, and he enjoyed it so much he forgot to return. Meanwhile, King Yan of Xu rebelled. King Mu rode his thousand-li horses each day to attack King Yan of Xu and decisively defeated him. He then granted Zaofu the city of Zhao. From this time onward, they became the Zhao clan.
3
è‡ªé€ çˆ¶å·²ä¸‹å…­ä¸–è‡³å¥„çˆ¶ï¼Œæ›°å…¬ä»²ï¼Œå‘¨å®£ç‹æ™‚ä¼æˆï¼Œç‚ºå¾¡ã€‚ åŠåƒç•æˆ°ï¼Œå¥„çˆ¶è„«å®£ç‹ã€‚ å¥„çˆ¶ç”Ÿå”å¸¶ã€‚ å”å¸¶ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œå‘¨å¹½ç‹ç„¡é“ï¼Œå»å‘¨å¦‚æ™‰ï¼Œäº‹æ™‰æ–‡ä¾¯ï¼Œå§‹å»ºè¶™æ°äºæ™‰åœ‹ã€‚
Six generations after Zaofu came Yanfu, also known as Gongzhong. During King Xuan of Zhou's reign, he campaigned against the Rong and served as charioteer. During the battle at Qianmu, Yanfu rescued King Xuan. Yanfu begat Shudai. During Shudai's time, King You of Zhou was tyrannical. He left Zhou and went to Jin, served Duke Wen of Jin, and first established the Zhao clan in the state of Jin.
4
è‡ªå”å¸¶ä»¥ä¸‹ï¼Œè¶™å®—ç›Šèˆˆï¼Œäº”ä¸–è€Œï¼ˆç”Ÿï¼‰ï¼»è‡³ï¼½è¶™å¤™ã€‚
From Shudai onward, the Zhao lineage grew increasingly prominent, and after five generations reached Zhao Shu.
5
è¶™å¤™ï¼Œæ™‰ç»å…¬ä¹‹åå…­å¹´ä¼éœã€é­ã€è€¿ï¼Œè€Œè¶™å¤™ç‚ºå°‡ä¼éœã€‚ éœå…¬æ±‚å¥”é½Šã€‚ æ™‰å¤§æ—±ï¼Œåœä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ã€Œéœå¤ªå±±ç‚ºç¥Ÿã€ã€‚ ä½¿è¶™å¤™å¬éœå›æ–¼é½Šï¼Œå¾©ä¹‹ï¼Œä»¥å¥‰éœå¤ªå±±ä¹‹ç¥€ï¼Œæ™‰å¾©ç©°ã€‚ æ™‰ç»å…¬è³œè¶™å¤™è€¿ã€‚
Zhao Shu, in Duke Xian of Jin's sixteenth year, attacked Huo, Wei, and Geng. Zhao Shu was the general who attacked Huo. Lord Qiu of Huo fled to Qi. Jin suffered a great drought. They divined the cause and were told, 'Mount Tai of Huo is causing this calamity.' They sent Zhao Shu to summon the Lord of Huo from Qi and restore him, so that he could offer sacrifices to Mount Tai of Huo. Jin became prosperous again. Duke Xian of Jin granted Zhao Shu the city of Geng.
6
å¤™ç”Ÿå…±å­Ÿï¼Œç•¶é­¯é–”å…¬ä¹‹å…ƒå¹´ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…±å­Ÿç”Ÿè¶™è¡°ï¼Œå­—å­é¤˜ã€‚
Shu begat Gong Meng, which was in the first year of Duke Min of Lu. Gong Meng begat Zhao Shuai, whose courtesy name was Ziyv.
7
è¶™è¡°åœäº‹æ™‰ç»å…¬åŠè«¸å…¬å­ï¼Œè«å‰ï¼› åœäº‹å…¬å­é‡è€³ï¼Œå‰ï¼Œå³äº‹é‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³ä»¥é©ªå§¬ä¹‹äº‚äº¡å¥”ç¿Ÿï¼Œè¶™è¡°å¾ã€‚ ç¿Ÿä¼å»§å’å¦‚ï¼Œå¾—äºŒå¥³ï¼Œç¿Ÿä»¥å…¶å°‘å¥³å¦»é‡è€³ï¼Œé•·å¥³å¦»è¶™è¡°è€Œç”Ÿç›¾ã€‚ åˆï¼Œé‡è€³åœ¨æ™‰æ™‚ï¼Œè¶™è¡°å¦»äº¦ç”Ÿè¶™åŒã€è¶™æ‹¬ã€è¶™å¬°é½Šã€‚ è¶™è¡°å¾é‡è€³å‡ºäº¡ï¼Œå‡¡åä¹å¹´ï¼Œå¾—ååœ‹ã€‚ é‡è€³ç‚ºæ™‰æ–‡å…¬ï¼Œè¶™è¡°ç‚ºåŸå¤§å¤«ï¼Œå±…åŸï¼Œä»»åœ‹æ”¿ã€‚ æ–‡å…¬æ‰€ä»¥ååœ‹åŠéœ¸ï¼Œå¤šè¶™è¡°è¨ˆç­–ï¼Œèªåœ¨æ™‰äº‹ä¸­ã€‚
Zhao Shuai divined about serving Duke Xian of Jin and the various princes, but none of the divinations were auspicious. When he divined about serving Prince Chong'er, it was auspicious, so he served Chong'er. Because of the disorder caused by Lady Li, Chong'er fled to the Di. Zhao Shuai followed him. The Di attacked Xia Jiuru and obtained two women. The Di gave their younger daughter to Chong'er as wife, and gave the elder daughter to Zhao Shuai as wife. She gave birth to Dun. Initially, when Chong'er was still in Jin, Zhao Shuai's wife also gave birth to Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi. Zhao Shuai followed Chong'er into exile. After nineteen years altogether, they were able to return to the state. Chong'er became Duke Wen of Jin. Zhao Shuai became the grand master of Yuan, resided in Yuan, and took charge of state affairs. Duke Wen's return to the state and his hegemony were mostly due to Zhao Shuai's strategies. This is recorded in the Jin annals.
8
è¶™è¡°æ—¢åæ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰ä¹‹å¦»å›ºè¦è¿ç¿Ÿå¦»ï¼Œè€Œä»¥å…¶å­ç›¾ç‚ºé©å—£ï¼Œæ™‰å¦»ä¸‰å­çš†ä¸‹äº‹ä¹‹ã€‚ æ™‰è¥„å…¬ä¹‹å…­å¹´ï¼Œè€Œè¶™è¡°å’ï¼Œè¬šç‚ºæˆå­£ã€‚
After Zhao Shuai returned to Jin, Duke Wen's wife strongly insisted on welcoming the Di wife, and made her son Dun the proper heir. Duke Wen's wife's three sons all served below him. In the sixth year of Duke Xiang of Jin, Zhao Shuai died. His posthumous name was Cheng Ji.
9
è¶™ç›¾ä»£æˆå­£ä»»åœ‹æ”¿äºŒå¹´è€Œæ™‰è¥„å…¬å’ï¼Œå¤ªå­å¤·çš‹å¹´å°‘ã€‚ ç›¾ç‚ºåœ‹å¤šé›£ï¼Œæ¬²ç«‹è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿé›ã€‚ é›æ™‚åœ¨ç§¦ï¼Œä½¿ä½¿è¿ä¹‹ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ¯æ—¥å¤œå•¼æ³£ï¼Œé “é¦–è¬‚è¶™ç›¾æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…ˆå›ä½•ç½ªï¼Œé‡‹å…¶é©å­è€Œæ›´æ±‚å›ï¼Ÿã€ è¶™ç›¾æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œæå…¶å®—èˆ‡å¤§å¤«è¥²èª…ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒé‚ç«‹å¤ªå­ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºéˆå…¬ï¼Œç™¼å…µè·æ‰€è¿è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿæ–¼ç§¦è€…ã€‚ éˆå…¬æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œè¶™ç›¾ç›Šå°ˆåœ‹æ”¿ã€‚
Zhao Dun replaced Cheng Ji and took charge of state affairs. Two years later, Duke Xiang of Jin died. Crown Prince Yi Gao was young. Because the state had many difficulties, Dun wished to establish Duke Xiang's younger brother Yong as ruler. Yong was then in Qin, so they sent an envoy to welcome him. The crown prince's mother wept and wailed day and night. She kowtowed and said to Zhao Dun, 'What crime did the former lord commit? Why abandon his proper son and seek another lord?' Zhao Dun was troubled by this. He feared that his clan and the grand masters would suddenly execute him. So he established the crown prince as ruler. This was Duke Ling. He sent troops to block those who were welcoming Duke Xiang's younger brother from Qin. After Duke Ling was established as ruler, Zhao Dun increasingly monopolized control of state affairs.
10
éˆå…¬ç«‹åå››å¹´ï¼Œç›Šé©•ã€‚ è¶™ç›¾é©Ÿè««ï¼Œéˆå…¬å¼—è½ã€‚ åŠé£Ÿç†Šè¹¯ï¼Œèƒ¹ä¸ç†Ÿï¼Œæ®ºå®°äººï¼ŒæŒå…¶å°¸å‡ºï¼Œè¶™ç›¾è¦‹ä¹‹ã€‚ éˆå…¬ç”±æ­¤æ‡¼ï¼Œæ¬²æ®ºç›¾ã€‚ ç›¾ç´ ä»æ„›äººï¼Œå˜—æ‰€é£Ÿæ¡‘ä¸‹é¤“äººåææ•‘ç›¾ï¼Œç›¾ä»¥å¾—äº¡ã€‚ æœªå‡ºå¢ƒï¼Œè€Œè¶™ç©¿å¼’éˆå…¬è€Œç«‹è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿé»‘è‡€ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæˆå…¬ã€‚ è¶™ç›¾å¾©åï¼Œä»»åœ‹æ”¿ã€‚ å›å­è­ç›¾ã€Œç‚ºæ­£å¿ï¼Œäº¡ä¸å‡ºå¢ƒï¼Œåä¸è¨è³Šã€ï¼Œæ•…å¤ªå²æ›¸æ›°ã€Œè¶™ç›¾å¼’å…¶å›ã€ã€‚ æ™‰æ™¯å…¬æ™‚è€Œè¶™ç›¾å’ï¼Œè¬šç‚ºå®£å­Ÿï¼Œå­æœ”å—£ã€‚
Duke Ling had been on the throne for fourteen years and grew increasingly arrogant. Zhao Dun repeatedly admonished him, but Duke Ling would not listen. When Duke Ling was eating bear's paw, the stew was not cooked. He killed the butcher and had his corpse carried out. Zhao Dun saw this. Duke Ling became fearful because of this and wished to kill Dun. Dun was usually benevolent and loved people. Once, a hungry person he had fed under a mulberry tree returned and protected him, saving Dun. This is how Dun was able to escape. Before Zhao Dun had even left the borders, Zhao Chuan assassinated Duke Ling and established Duke Xiang's younger brother Heitun as ruler. This was Duke Cheng. Zhao Dun returned again and took charge of state affairs. The gentleman criticized Zhao Dun, saying, 'As chief minister, when his lord went into exile, he did not leave the borders with him. When he returned, he did not punish the traitor.' Therefore, the grand scribe wrote, 'Zhao Dun assassinated his lord.' During the reign of Duke Jing of Jin, Zhao Dun died. His posthumous name was Xuan Meng. His son Zhao Shuo succeeded him.
11
è¶™æœ”ï¼Œæ™‰æ™¯å…¬ä¹‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæœ”ç‚ºæ™‰å°‡ä¸‹è»æ•‘é„­ï¼Œèˆ‡æ¥šèŠç‹æˆ°æ²³ä¸Šã€‚ æœ”å¨¶æ™‰æˆå…¬å§Šç‚ºå¤«äººã€‚
Zhao Shuo, in the third year of Duke Jing of Jin, served as the general of Jin's lower army to save Zheng. He battled King Zhuang of Chu on the Yellow River. Zhao Shuo married Duke Cheng of Jin's elder sister as his wife.
12
æ™‰æ™¯å…¬ä¹‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œå¤§å¤«å± å²¸è³ˆæ¬²èª…è¶™æ°ã€‚ åˆï¼Œè¶™ç›¾åœ¨æ™‚ï¼Œå¤¢è¦‹å”å¸¶æŒè¦è€Œå“­ï¼Œç”šæ‚²ï¼› å·²è€Œç¬‘ï¼Œæ‹Šæ‰‹ä¸”æ­Œã€‚ ç›¾åœä¹‹ï¼Œå…†çµ•è€Œå¾Œå¥½ã€‚ è¶™å²æ´å ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å¤¢ç”šæƒ¡ï¼Œéå›ä¹‹èº«ï¼Œä¹ƒå›ä¹‹å­ï¼Œç„¶äº¦å›ä¹‹å’ã€‚ è‡³å­«ï¼Œè¶™å°‡ä¸–ç›Šè¡°ã€‚ã€ å± å²¸è³ˆè€…ï¼Œå§‹æœ‰å¯µæ–¼éˆå…¬ï¼ŒåŠè‡³æ–¼æ™¯å…¬è€Œè³ˆç‚ºå¸å¯‡ï¼Œå°‡ä½œé›£ï¼Œä¹ƒæ²»éˆå…¬ä¹‹è³Šä»¥è‡´è¶™ç›¾ï¼Œéå‘Šè«¸å°‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œç›¾é›–ä¸çŸ¥ï¼ŒçŒ¶ç‚ºè³Šé¦–ã€‚ ä»¥è‡£å¼’å›ï¼Œå­å­«åœ¨æœï¼Œä½•ä»¥æ‡²ç½ªï¼Ÿ è«‹èª…ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ éŸ“å¥æ›°ï¼šã€Œéˆå…¬é‡è³Šï¼Œè¶™ç›¾åœ¨å¤–ï¼Œå¾å…ˆå›ä»¥ç‚ºç„¡ç½ªï¼Œæ•…ä¸èª…ã€‚ ä»Šè«¸å›å°‡èª…å…¶å¾Œï¼Œæ˜¯éå…ˆå›ä¹‹æ„è€Œä»Šå¦„èª…ã€‚ å¦„èª…è¬‚ä¹‹äº‚ã€‚ è‡£æœ‰å¤§äº‹è€Œå›ä¸èï¼Œæ˜¯ç„¡å›ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å± å²¸è³ˆä¸è½ã€‚ éŸ“å¥å‘Šè¶™æœ”è¶£äº¡ã€‚ æœ”ä¸è‚¯ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå­å¿…ä¸çµ•è¶™ç¥€ï¼Œæœ”æ­»ä¸æ¨ã€‚ã€ éŸ“å¥è¨±è«¾ï¼Œç¨±ç–¾ä¸å‡ºã€‚ è³ˆä¸è«‹è€Œæ“…èˆ‡è«¸å°‡æ”»è¶™æ°æ–¼ä¸‹å®®ï¼Œæ®ºè¶™æœ”ã€è¶™åŒã€è¶™æ‹¬ã€è¶™å¬°é½Šï¼Œçš†æ»…å…¶æ—ã€‚
In the third year of Duke Jing of Jin, the grand master Tu Anjia wished to execute the Zhao clan. Initially, while Zhao Dun was still alive, he dreamed that he saw Shudai holding his waist and crying. It was very sorrowful. Then he laughed, clapped his hands, and sang. Zhao Dun divined about it. The omen was broken at first, but then became favorable. The Zhao scribe Yuan interpreted it and said, 'This dream is very bad. It does not refer to your own body, but to your son's. However, it is also your own fault.' 'It will reach your grandson. The Zhao clan will decline generation by generation.' Tu Anjia had initially found favor with Duke Ling. When Duke Jing's reign came, Jia became the judicial minister. He was about to stir up trouble, so he investigated Duke Ling's assassin to implicate Zhao Dun. He told all the generals, 'Even though Zhao Dun did not know about it, he was still the head of the traitors.' 'A minister assassinated his lord, yet his descendants remain in the court. How can we punish this crime?' 'I request that they be executed.' Han Que said, 'Duke Ling encountered a traitor. Zhao Dun was outside. My former lord considered him innocent, so he did not execute him.' Now you lords are about to execute his descendants. This is not my former lord's intention, and you are recklessly executing them now.' Reckless execution is called disorder.' 'A minister has a great matter and his lord does not hear about it. This means he has no lord.' Tu Anjia did not listen. Han Que told Zhao Shuo to hasten and flee. Zhao Shuo was not willing. He said, 'You must not cut off the Zhao sacrifices. I will die without regret.' Han Que promised and claimed illness so as not to go out. Jia did not request permission but arbitrarily joined with the various generals to attack the Zhao clan at the lower palace. They killed Zhao Shuo, Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi. They extinguished all their clans.
13
è¶™æœ”å¦»æˆå…¬å§Šï¼Œæœ‰éºè…¹ï¼Œèµ°å…¬å®®åŒ¿ã€‚ è¶™æœ”å®¢æ›°å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ï¼Œæµè‡¼è¬‚æœ”å‹äººç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œèƒ¡ä¸æ­»ï¼Ÿã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ”ä¹‹å©¦æœ‰éºè…¹ï¼Œè‹¥å¹¸è€Œç”·ï¼Œå¾å¥‰ä¹‹ï¼› å³å¥³ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¾å¾æ­»è€³ã€‚ã€ å±…ç„¡ä½•ï¼Œè€Œæœ”å©¦å…èº«ï¼Œç”Ÿç”·ã€‚ å± å²¸è³ˆèä¹‹ï¼Œç´¢æ–¼å®®ä¸­ã€‚ å¤«äººç½®å…’å±ç½…ç¥æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™å®—æ»…ä¹ï¼Œè‹¥è™Ÿï¼› å³ä¸æ»…ï¼Œè‹¥ç„¡è²ã€‚ã€ åŠç´¢ï¼Œå…’ç«Ÿç„¡è²ã€‚ å·²è„«ï¼Œç¨‹å¬°è¬‚å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä¸€ç´¢ä¸å¾—ï¼Œå¾Œå¿…ä¸”å¾©ç´¢ä¹‹ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œç«‹å­¤èˆ‡æ­»å­°é›£ï¼Ÿã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­»æ˜“ï¼Œç«‹å­¤é›£è€³ã€‚ã€ å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ°å…ˆå›é‡å­åšï¼Œå­å½Šç‚ºå…¶é›£è€…ï¼Œå¾ç‚ºå…¶æ˜“è€…ï¼Œè«‹å…ˆæ­»ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒäºŒäººè¬€å–ä»–äººå¬°å…’è² ä¹‹ï¼Œè¡£ä»¥æ–‡è‘†ï¼ŒåŒ¿å±±ä¸­ã€‚ ç¨‹å¬°å‡ºï¼Œè¬¬è¬‚è«¸å°‡è»æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¬°ä¸è‚–ï¼Œä¸èƒ½ç«‹è¶™å­¤ã€‚ èª°èƒ½èˆ‡æˆ‘åƒé‡‘ï¼Œå¾å‘Šè¶™æ°å­¤è™•ã€‚ã€ è«¸å°‡çš†å–œï¼Œè¨±ä¹‹ï¼Œç™¼å¸«éš¨ç¨‹å¬°æ”»å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ã€‚ æµè‡¼è¬¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå°äººå“‰ç¨‹å¬°ï¼ æ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ä¸èƒ½æ­»ï¼Œèˆ‡æˆ‘è¬€åŒ¿è¶™æ°å­¤å…’ï¼Œä»Šåˆè³£æˆ‘ã€‚ ç¸±ä¸èƒ½ç«‹ï¼Œè€Œå¿è³£ä¹‹ä¹ï¼ã€ æŠ±å…’å‘¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©ä¹å¤©ä¹ï¼ è¶™æ°å­¤å…’ä½•ç½ªï¼Ÿ è«‹æ´»ä¹‹ï¼Œç¨æ®ºæµè‡¼å¯ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ è«¸å°‡ä¸è¨±ï¼Œé‚æ®ºæµè‡¼èˆ‡å­¤å…’ã€‚ è«¸å°‡ä»¥ç‚ºè¶™æ°å­¤å…’è‰¯å·²æ­»ï¼Œçš†å–œã€‚ ç„¶è¶™æ°çœŸå­¤ä¹ƒååœ¨ï¼Œç¨‹å¬°å’èˆ‡ä¿±åŒ¿å±±ä¸­ã€‚
Zhao Shuo's wife, who was Duke Cheng's elder sister, had a posthumous child. She fled and hid in the ducal palace. Zhao Shuo's guest was named Gongsun Chujiu. Chujiu said to Zhao Shuo's friend Cheng Ying, 'Why don't you die?' Cheng Ying said, 'Zhao Shuo's wife has a posthumous child. If fortunately it's a boy, I will support him.' 'If it's a girl, I will just die later.' Not long after, Zhao Shuo's wife gave birth to a boy. Tu Anjia heard about it and searched within the palace. The lady placed the child and rebuked the priest at the crevice, saying, 'Has the Zhao lineage been extinguished? If so, cry out.' 'If not extinguished, make no sound.' When they searched, the child made no sound at all. Once they had escaped, Cheng Ying said to Gongsun Chujiu, 'Now that one search didn't find him, they will surely search again later. What should we do?' Gongsun Chujiu said, 'Which is more difficult: establishing an orphan or dying?' Cheng Ying said, 'Dying is easy. Establishing an orphan is difficult.' Gongsun Chujiu said, 'The former lords of the Zhao clan treated you generously. You should take on the difficult task. I will take on the easy one. Let me die first.' So the two men planned to take another person's infant, carry it, clothe it in a patterned quilt, and hide it in the mountains. Cheng Ying went out and falsely told the various generals, 'I am unworthy and cannot establish the Zhao orphan.' 'Whoever gives me a thousand pieces of gold, I will tell them where the Zhao orphan is.' All the generals were happy and promised him. They sent troops and followed Cheng Ying to attack Gongsun Chujiu. Chujiu falsely said, 'What a petty man Cheng Ying is!' 'In the former difficulty at the lower palace, you couldn't die with them. You planned with me to hide the Zhao orphan. Now you're selling me out again.' 'Even if you can't establish him, how can you bear to sell him out!' He embraced the child and called out, 'Heaven! Oh heaven!' What crime has the Zhao orphan committed? 'Please let him live. It would be enough to kill only Chujiu.' The generals would not permit it, so they killed Chujiu and the orphan. The generals believed that the Zhao orphan was truly dead, and they were all happy. However, the true Zhao orphan was actually still alive. Cheng Ying finally hid in the mountains together with him.
14
å±…åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æ™¯å…¬ç–¾ï¼Œåœä¹‹ï¼Œå¤§æ¥­ä¹‹å¾Œä¸é‚è€…ç‚ºç¥Ÿã€‚ æ™¯å…¬å•éŸ“å¥ï¼Œå¥çŸ¥è¶™å­¤åœ¨ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤§æ¥­ä¹‹å¾Œåœ¨æ™‰çµ•ç¥€è€…ï¼Œå…¶è¶™æ°ä¹ï¼Ÿ å¤«è‡ªä¸­è¡è€…çš†å¬´å§“ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸­è¡äººé¢é³¥å™£ï¼Œé™ä½æ®·å¸å¤§æˆŠï¼ŒåŠå‘¨å¤©å­ï¼Œçš†æœ‰æ˜å¾·ã€‚ ä¸‹åŠå¹½å²ç„¡é“ï¼Œè€Œå”å¸¶å»å‘¨é©æ™‰ï¼Œäº‹å…ˆå›æ–‡ä¾¯ï¼Œè‡³äºæˆå…¬ï¼Œä¸–æœ‰ç«‹åŠŸï¼Œæœªå˜—çµ•ç¥€ã€‚ ä»Šå¾å›ç¨æ»…è¶™å®—ï¼Œåœ‹äººå“€ä¹‹ï¼Œæ•…è¦‹é¾œç­–ã€‚ å”¯å›åœ–ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ™¯å…¬å•ï¼šã€Œè¶™å°šæœ‰å¾Œå­å­«ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ éŸ“å¥å…·ä»¥å¯¦å‘Šã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯æ™¯å…¬ä¹ƒèˆ‡éŸ“å¥è¬€ç«‹è¶™å­¤å…’ï¼Œå¬è€ŒåŒ¿ä¹‹å®®ä¸­ã€‚ è«¸å°‡å…¥å•ç–¾ï¼Œæ™¯å…¬å› éŸ“å¥ä¹‹çœ¾ä»¥è„…è«¸å°‡è€Œè¦‹è¶™å­¤ã€‚ è¶™å­¤åæ›°æ­¦ã€‚ è«¸å°‡ä¸å¾—å·²ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ï¼Œå± å²¸è³ˆç‚ºä¹‹ï¼ŒçŸ¯ä»¥å›å‘½ï¼Œå¹¶å‘½ç¾¤è‡£ã€‚ éç„¶ï¼Œå­°æ•¢ä½œé›£ï¼ å¾®å›ä¹‹ç–¾ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£å›ºä¸”è«‹ç«‹è¶™å¾Œã€‚ ä»Šå›æœ‰å‘½ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£ä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¬è¶™æ­¦ã€ç¨‹å¬°éæ‹œè«¸å°‡ï¼Œé‚åèˆ‡ç¨‹å¬°ã€è¶™æ­¦æ”»å± å²¸è³ˆï¼Œæ»…å…¶æ—ã€‚ å¾©èˆ‡è¶™æ­¦ç”°é‚‘å¦‚æ•…ã€‚
Fifteen years passed. Duke Jing of Jin fell ill. They divined the cause and found that descendants of great enterprises who had not succeeded were causing the trouble. Duke Jing asked Han Que. Que knew the Zhao orphan was alive, so he said, 'The descendants of great enterprises in Jin who have had their sacrifices cut off - could it be the Zhao clan?' Indeed, all those descended from Zhong Yan have the Ying surname. Zhong Yan had a human face and bird beak. He descended to assist Emperor Da Wu of Yin, and the Zhou kings. They all possessed bright virtue. It continued down to the tyrannical reigns of You and Li. Shudai left Zhou and went to Jin, served the former lord Duke Wen, down to Duke Cheng. Each generation established merit and never had their sacrifices cut off. Now my lord alone has extinguished the Zhao lineage. The people of the state grieve for it, which is why it appears in the turtle-shell divination. Only my lord should decide on this.' Duke Jing asked, 'Does the Zhao clan still have any descendants?' Han Que told him the full truth. Thereupon Duke Jing planned with Han Que to establish the Zhao orphan. They summoned him and hid him in the palace. The generals entered to inquire about his illness. Duke Jing took advantage of Han Que's supporters to threaten the generals and show them the Zhao orphan. The Zhao orphan was named Wu. The generals had no choice but to say, 'In the former difficulty at the lower palace, Tu Anjia did it. He forged the lord's command and commanded all the ministers.' If not so, who would dare to make trouble!' If not for my lord's illness, all the ministers would certainly have requested to establish a Zhao successor.' Now that my lord has commanded, it is also the ministers' wish.' Thereupon they summoned Zhao Wu and Cheng Ying. They bowed to all the generals, then turned around and joined with Cheng Ying and Zhao Wu to attack Tu Anjia and extinguish his clan. They restored Zhao Wu's fields and towns as they were before.

åŠè¶™æ­¦å† ï¼Œç‚ºæˆäººï¼Œç¨‹å¬°ä¹ƒè¾­è«¸å¤§å¤«ï¼Œè¬‚è¶™æ­¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ï¼Œçš†èƒ½æ­»ã€‚ æˆ‘éä¸èƒ½æ­»ï¼Œæˆ‘æ€ç«‹è¶™æ°ä¹‹å¾Œã€‚ ä»Šè¶™æ­¦æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œç‚ºæˆäººï¼Œå¾©æ•…ä½ï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡ä¸‹å ±è¶™å®£å­Ÿèˆ‡å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ã€‚ã€ è¶™æ­¦å•¼æ³£é “é¦–å›ºè«‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¦é¡˜è‹¦ç­‹éª¨ä»¥å ±å­è‡³æ­»ï¼Œè€Œå­å¿å»æˆ‘æ­»ä¹ï¼ã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ã€‚ å½¼ä»¥æˆ‘ç‚ºèƒ½æˆäº‹ï¼Œæ•…å…ˆæˆ‘æ­»ï¼› ä»Šæˆ‘ä¸å ±ï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥æˆ‘äº‹ç‚ºä¸æˆã€‚ã€ é‚è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ è¶™æ­¦æœé½Šè¡°ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç‚ºä¹‹ç¥­é‚‘ï¼Œæ˜¥ç§‹ç¥ ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸–ä¸–å‹¿çµ•ã€‚
When Zhao Wu came of age and was capped, becoming an adult, Cheng Ying then resigned from the grand masters and said to Zhao Wu, 'In the former difficulty at the lower palace, everyone was able to die.' I was not unable to die. I thought about establishing the Zhao clan's successor.' Now that Zhao Wu has been established and become an adult, recovering his former position, I will go below to repay Zhao Xuanmeng and Gongsun Chujiu.' Zhao Wu wept and wailed, kowtowing and firmly requesting, saying, 'Wu wishes to toil his sinews and bones to repay you until death. Yet how can you bear to leave me and die!' Cheng Ying said, 'It cannot be.' He considered me able to accomplish the affairs, so he died before me;' Now if I do not repay him, this means my affairs were not accomplished.' Then he committed suicide. Zhao Wu wore mourning garments for three years. They established a sacrificial town for him and sacrificed to him in spring and autumn. This was never cut off through the generations.

Eleven years after the Zhao clan recovered their position, Duke Li of Jin killed his three grand masters of the Xi clan. Luan Shu feared he would be implicated, so he assassinated his lord Duke Li and established Duke Xiang's great-grandson Zhou as ruler. This was Duke Dao. From this time onward, the grand masters of Jin gradually grew stronger.

Zhao Wu continued the Zhao lineage for twenty-seven years. Duke Ping of Jin was established as ruler. In Duke Ping's twelfth year, Zhao Wu became the chief minister. In the thirteenth year, Jizi of Yanling from Wu came as envoy to Jin and said, 'The governance of Jin will ultimately belong to the descendants of Zhao Wuzi, Han Xuanzhi, and Wei Xianzi.' Zhao Wu died. His posthumous name was Wenzi.

Wenzi begat Jingshu. During Jingshu's time, Duke Jing of Qi sent Yan Ying to Jin. Yan Ying spoke with Shu Xiang of Jin. Yan Ying said, 'The governance of Qi will ultimately belong to the Tian clan.' Zhao Jianzi was in office. In the ninth year of Duke Qing of Jin, Jianzi was about to unite the feudal lords to defend Zhou. The next year, they brought King Jing of Zhou back to Zhou, avoiding the matter of Di Zi Chao.

In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin, the six ministers executed the ducal clans of the Qi and Yangshe families according to law. è¶™ç°¡å­ç–¾ï¼Œäº”æ—¥ä¸çŸ¥äººï¼Œå¤§å¤«çš†æ‡¼ã€‚ é†«æ‰éµ²è¦–ä¹‹ï¼Œå‡ºï¼Œè‘£å®‰äºå•ã€‚ æ‰éµ²æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¡€è„ˆæ²»ä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œä½•æ€ªï¼ åœ¨æ˜”ç§¦ç¹†å…¬å˜—å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œä¸ƒæ—¥è€Œå¯¤ã€‚ å¯¤ä¹‹æ—¥ï¼Œå‘Šå…¬å­«æ”¯èˆ‡å­è¼¿æ›°ï¼šã€æˆ‘ä¹‹å¸æ‰€ç”šæ¨‚ã€‚ å¾æ‰€ä»¥ä¹…è€…ï¼Œé©æœ‰å­¸ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¸å‘Šæˆ‘ï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹å°‡å¤§äº‚ï¼Œäº”ä¸–ä¸å®‰ï¼› å…¶å¾Œå°‡éœ¸ï¼Œæœªè€è€Œæ­»ï¼› éœ¸è€…ä¹‹å­ä¸”ä»¤è€Œåœ‹ç”·å¥³ç„¡åˆ¥ã€‚ã€ã€ å…¬å­«æ”¯æ›¸è€Œè—ä¹‹ï¼Œç§¦è®–æ–¼æ˜¯å‡ºçŸ£ã€‚ ç»å…¬ä¹‹äº‚ï¼Œæ–‡å…¬ä¹‹éœ¸ï¼Œè€Œè¥„å…¬æ•—ç§¦å¸«æ–¼æ®½è€Œæ­¸ç¸±æ·«ï¼Œæ­¤å­ä¹‹æ‰€èã€‚ ä»Šä¸»å›ä¹‹ç–¾èˆ‡ä¹‹åŒï¼Œä¸å‡ºä¸‰æ—¥ç–¾å¿…é–’ï¼Œé–’å¿…æœ‰è¨€ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€
Zhao Jianzi fell ill. For five days he was unconscious. All the grand masters were fearful. The physician Bian Que examined him and went out. Dong Anyu asked him about it. Bian Que said, 'His blood vessels are in good order. What's so strange about that!' In former times, Duke Mu of Qin was once like this. He awoke after seven days. On the day he awoke, he told Gongsun Zhi and Zi Yu, 'I was very happy in the Emperor's realm.' The reason I stayed so long was that I had studies to pursue.' The Emperor told me, 'Jin will suffer great disorder. For five generations there will be no peace.' Its descendants will become hegemon, but will die before growing old.' The hegemon's son will also give commands, and in the state there will be no distinction between males and females.'' Gongsun Zhi wrote it down and hid it away. The Qin prophecy thus came into being. Duke Xian's disorder, Duke Wen's hegemony, and Duke Xiang's defeat of the Qin army at Xiao followed by his indulgent lewdness upon return - this is what your son has heard.' Now your master's illness is the same as that. Within three days the illness will ease, and when it eases he will surely have words to say.'

å±…äºŒæ—¥åŠï¼Œç°¡å­å¯¤ã€‚ èªå¤§å¤«æ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘ä¹‹å¸æ‰€ç”šæ¨‚ï¼Œèˆ‡ç™¾ç¥æ¸¸æ–¼éˆå¤©ï¼Œå»£æ¨‚ä¹å¥è¬èˆï¼Œä¸é¡ä¸‰ä»£ä¹‹æ¨‚ï¼Œå…¶è²å‹•äººå¿ƒã€‚ æœ‰ä¸€ç†Šæ¬²ä¾†æ´æˆ‘ï¼Œå¸å‘½æˆ‘å°„ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸­ç†Šï¼Œç†Šæ­»ã€‚ åˆæœ‰ä¸€ç¾†ä¾†ï¼Œæˆ‘åˆå°„ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸­ç¾†ï¼Œç¾†æ­»ã€‚ å¸ç”šå–œï¼Œè³œæˆ‘äºŒç¬¥ï¼Œçš†æœ‰å‰¯ã€‚ å¾è¦‹å…’åœ¨å¸å´ï¼Œå¸å±¬æˆ‘ä¸€ç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€åŠè€Œå­ä¹‹å£¯ä¹Ÿï¼Œä»¥è³œä¹‹ã€‚ã€ å¸å‘Šæˆ‘ï¼šã€æ™‰åœ‹ä¸”ä¸–è¡°ï¼Œä¸ƒä¸–è€Œäº¡ï¼Œå¬´å§“å°‡å¤§æ•—å‘¨äººæ–¼èŒƒé­ä¹‹è¥¿ï¼Œè€Œäº¦ä¸èƒ½æœ‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šä½™æ€è™èˆœä¹‹å‹³ï¼Œé©ä½™å°‡ä»¥å…¶èƒ„å¥³å­Ÿå§šé…è€Œä¸ƒä¸–ä¹‹å­«ã€‚ã€ã€ è‘£å®‰äºå—è¨€è€Œæ›¸è—ä¹‹ã€‚ ä»¥æ‰éµ²è¨€å‘Šç°¡å­ï¼Œç°¡å­è³œæ‰éµ²ç”°å››è¬ç•ã€‚
After two and a half days, Jianzi awoke. He spoke to the grand masters, saying, 'I was very happy in the Emperor's realm. I toured with the hundred gods in Jun Tian. The vast music had nine movements and ten thousand dances. It was unlike the music of the three dynasties. Its sound moved people's hearts.' There was a bear that wished to come attack me. The Emperor commanded me to shoot it. I hit the bear and it died.' Again there was a pi that came. I shot it again, hit the pi, and it died.' The Emperor was very happy and granted me two si, each with a deputy.' I saw a child at the Emperor's side. The Emperor entrusted me with a Di dog, saying, 'When your son grows strong, grant it to him.'' The Emperor told me, 'Jin will decline generation by generation. After seven generations it will perish. The Ying surname will greatly defeat the Zhou people west of Fan Kui, but will not be able to possess it either.' Now I think of Yu Shun's merits. I will match Meng Yao, the descendant woman, with your seven-generation grandson.'' Dong Anyu received the words and wrote them down to hide them away. They told Jianzi what Bian Que had said. Jianzi granted Bian Que forty thousand mu of fields.

ä»–æ—¥ï¼Œç°¡å­å‡ºï¼Œæœ‰äººç•¶é“ï¼Œè¾Ÿä¹‹ä¸å»ï¼Œå¾è€…æ€’ï¼Œå°‡åˆƒä¹‹ã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾æ¬²æœ‰è¬æ–¼ä¸»å›ã€‚ã€ å¾è€…ä»¥èã€‚ ç°¡å­å¬ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œè­†ï¼Œå¾æœ‰æ‰€è¦‹å­æ™£ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå±å·¦å³ï¼Œé¡˜æœ‰è¬ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å±äººã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸»å›ä¹‹ç–¾ï¼Œè‡£åœ¨å¸å´ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¶ï¼Œæœ‰ä¹‹ã€‚ å­ä¹‹è¦‹æˆ‘ï¼Œæˆ‘ä½•ç‚ºï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¸ä»¤ä¸»å›å°„ç†Šèˆ‡ç¾†ï¼Œçš†æ­»ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜¯ï¼Œä¸”ä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹ä¸”æœ‰å¤§é›£ï¼Œä¸»å›é¦–ä¹‹ã€‚ å¸ä»¤ä¸»å›æ»…äºŒå¿ï¼Œå¤«ç†Šèˆ‡ç¾†çš†å…¶ç¥–ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¸è³œæˆ‘äºŒç¬¥çš†æœ‰å‰¯ï¼Œä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸»å›ä¹‹å­å°‡å…‹äºŒåœ‹æ–¼ç¿Ÿï¼Œçš†å­å§“ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾è¦‹å…’åœ¨å¸å´ï¼Œå¸å±¬æˆ‘ä¸€ç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Œæ›°ã€åŠè€Œå­ä¹‹é•·ä»¥è³œä¹‹ã€ã€‚ å¤«å…’ä½•è¬‚ä»¥è³œç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…’ï¼Œä¸»å›ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç¿ŸçŠ¬è€…ï¼Œä»£ä¹‹å…ˆä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸»å›ä¹‹å­ä¸”å¿…æœ‰ä»£ã€‚ åŠä¸»å›ä¹‹å¾Œå—£ï¼Œä¸”æœ‰é©æ”¿è€Œèƒ¡æœï¼Œå¹¶äºŒåœ‹æ–¼ç¿Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å•å…¶å§“è€Œå»¶ä¹‹ä»¥å®˜ã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£é‡äººï¼Œè‡´å¸å‘½è€³ã€‚ã€ é‚ä¸è¦‹ã€‚ ç°¡å­æ›¸è—ä¹‹åºœã€‚
Another day, Jianzi went out. Someone blocked the road. When they tried to avoid him he wouldn't go away. The followers grew angry and were about to cut him down. The one blocking the road said, 'I wish to have an audience with my master lord.' The followers reported this to him. Jianzi summoned him and said, 'Yu, I have something I want to tell you clearly.' The one blocking the road said, 'Dismiss those on the left and right. I wish to have an audience.' Jianzi dismissed the others. The one blocking the road said, 'During my master's illness, I was at the Emperor's side.' Jianzi said, 'Yes, I had that.' You saw me there. What was I doing?' The one blocking the road said, 'The Emperor commanded my master lord to shoot the bear and the pi. They all died.' Jianzi said, 'That's right. And what else?' The one blocking the road said, 'Jin will have great difficulties. My master lord will head them.' The Emperor commanded my master lord to extinguish two ministers. Indeed, the bear and the pi were their ancestors.' Jianzi said, 'The Emperor granted me two si, each with a deputy. What does that mean?' The one blocking the road said, 'My master lord's son will conquer two countries in the Di region. They all have the Zi surname.' Jianzi said, 'I saw a child at the Emperor's side. The Emperor entrusted me with a Di dog, saying, "When your son grows up, grant it to him."' Indeed, what does the child have to do with granting the Di dog?' The one blocking the road said, 'The child is my master lord's son.' The Di dogs were the ancestors of Dai. My master lord's son will certainly have Dai. When it reaches my master lord's later successors, they will change the governance and adopt barbarian clothing, merging two countries in the Di region.' Jianzi asked his surname and invited him to take office. The one blocking the road said, 'I am a rustic. I only convey the Emperor's commands.' Then he was not seen again. Jianzi wrote it down and hid it in his treasury.

ç•°æ—¥ï¼Œå§‘å¸ƒå­å¿è¦‹ç°¡å­ï¼Œç°¡å­éå¬è«¸å­ç›¸ä¹‹ã€‚ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡ç‚ºå°‡è»è€…ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ°å…¶æ»…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å˜—è¦‹ä¸€å­æ–¼è·¯ï¼Œæ®†å›ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å¬å­æ¯‹å¹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡å­å¿èµ·æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤çœŸå°‡è»çŸ£ï¼ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å…¶æ¯è³¤ï¼Œç¿Ÿå©¢ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¥šé“è²´å“‰ï¼Ÿã€ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©æ‰€æˆï¼Œé›–è³¤å¿…è²´ã€‚ã€ è‡ªæ˜¯ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œç°¡å­ç›¡å¬è«¸å­èˆ‡èªï¼Œæ¯‹å¹æœ€è³¢ã€‚ ç°¡å­ä¹ƒå‘Šè«¸å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾è—å¯¶ç¬¦æ–¼å¸¸å±±ä¸Šï¼Œå…ˆå¾—è€…è³ã€‚ã€ è«¸å­é¦³ä¹‹å¸¸å±±ä¸Šï¼Œæ±‚ï¼Œç„¡æ‰€å¾—ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹é‚„ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå·²å¾—ç¬¦çŸ£ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¥ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ¯‹å¹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å¸¸å±±ä¸Šè‡¨ä»£ï¼Œä»£å¯å–ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ–¼æ˜¯çŸ¥æ¯‹å¹æœè³¢ï¼Œä¹ƒå»¢å¤ªå­ä¼¯é­¯ï¼Œè€Œä»¥æ¯‹å¹ç‚ºå¤ªå­ã€‚
Another day, Gu Bu Zi Qing saw Jianzi. Jianzi summoned all his sons for him to examine their physiognomy. Zi Qing said, 'None of them are fit to be generals.' Jianzi said, 'Will the Zhao clan perhaps be extinguished?' Zi Qing said, 'I once saw a boy on the road. He is perhaps your son.' Jianzi summoned Zi Wu Xu. When Wu Xu arrived, Zi Qing stood up and said, 'This is truly a general!' Jianzi said, 'His mother is of low status. She is a Di slave. How could he be noble?' Zi Qing said, 'Heaven has bestowed this. Though of base birth, he will certainly be noble.' From that point on, Jianzi summoned all his sons to speak with them. Wu Xu was the most worthy. Jianzi then told his sons, 'I have hidden a treasure talisman on top of Chang Shan. Whoever gets it first will be rewarded.' His sons galloped to the top of Chang Shan and searched, but found nothing. Wu Xu returned and said, 'I have already obtained the talisman.' Jianzi said, 'Present it.' Wu Xu said, 'From the top of Chang Shan one can overlook Dai. Dai can be taken.' Jianzi thereupon knew that Wu Xu was indeed worthy. He abolished the crown prince Bo Lu and made Wu Xu crown prince instead.

å¾ŒäºŒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å®šå…¬ä¹‹åå››å¹´ï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œä½œäº‚ã€‚ æ˜å¹´æ˜¥ï¼Œç°¡å­è¬‚é‚¯é„²å¤§å¤«åˆæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¸æˆ‘è¡›å£«äº”ç™¾å®¶ï¼Œå¾å°‡ç½®ä¹‹æ™‰é™½ã€‚ã€ åˆè¨±è«¾ï¼Œæ­¸è€Œå…¶çˆ¶å…„ä¸è½ï¼Œå€è¨€ã€‚ è¶™é…æ•åˆï¼Œå›šä¹‹æ™‰é™½ã€‚ ä¹ƒå‘Šé‚¯é„²äººæ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘ç§æœ‰èª…åˆä¹Ÿï¼Œè«¸å›æ¬²èª°ç«‹ï¼Ÿã€ é‚æ®ºåˆã€‚ è¶™ç¨·ã€æ¶‰è³“ä»¥é‚¯é„²åã€‚ æ™‰å›ä½¿ç±ç§¦åœé‚¯é„²ã€‚ è€å¯…ã€èŒƒå‰å°„èˆ‡åˆå–„ï¼Œä¸è‚¯åŠ©ç§¦è€Œè¬€ä½œäº‚ï¼Œè‘£å®‰äºçŸ¥ä¹‹ã€‚ åæœˆï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°ä¼è¶™é…ï¼Œé…å¥”æ™‰é™½ï¼Œæ™‰äººåœä¹‹ã€‚ èŒƒå‰å°„ã€è€å¯…ä»‡äººé­è¥„ç­‰è¬€é€è€å¯…ï¼Œä»¥æ¢å¬°çˆ¶ä»£ä¹‹ï¼› é€å‰å°„ï¼Œä»¥èŒƒçš‹ç¹¹ä»£ä¹‹ã€‚ è€æ«Ÿè¨€æ–¼æ™‰ä¾¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›å‘½å¤§è‡£ï¼Œå§‹äº‚è€…æ­»ã€‚ ä»Šä¸‰è‡£å§‹äº‚è€Œç¨é€é…ï¼Œç”¨åˆ‘ä¸å‡ï¼Œè«‹çš†é€ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ åä¸€æœˆï¼Œè€æ«Ÿã€éŸ“ä¸ä½ã€é­å“†å¥‰å…¬å‘½ä»¥ä¼èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°ï¼Œä¸å…‹ã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°åä¼å…¬ï¼Œå…¬æ“Šä¹‹ï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ•—èµ°ã€‚ ä¸æœªï¼ŒäºŒå­å¥”æœæ­Œã€‚ éŸ“ã€é­ä»¥è¶™æ°ç‚ºè«‹ã€‚ åäºŒæœˆè¾›æœªï¼Œè¶™é…å…¥çµ³ï¼Œç›Ÿäºå…¬å®®ã€‚ å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯æ–‡å­è¬‚è¶™é…æ›°ï¼šã€ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œé›–ä¿¡ç‚ºäº‚ï¼Œå®‰äºç™¼ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯å®‰äºèˆ‡è¬€ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ™‰åœ‹æœ‰æ³•ï¼Œå§‹äº‚è€…æ­»ã€‚ å¤«äºŒå­å·²ä¼ç½ªè€Œå®‰äºç¨åœ¨ã€‚ã€ è¶™é…æ‚£ä¹‹ã€‚ å®‰äºæ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£æ­»ï¼Œè¶™æ°å®šï¼Œæ™‰åœ‹å¯§ï¼Œå¾æ­»æ™šçŸ£ã€‚ã€ é‚è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ è¶™æ°ä»¥å‘ŠçŸ¥ä¼¯ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œè¶™æ°å¯§ã€‚
Two years later, in the fourteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, the Fan and Zhongxing clans rebelled. The following spring, Jianzi told the grand master of Handan, Wu, 'Return to me five hundred households of Wei soldiers. I will station them in Jinyang.' Wu promised, but when he returned home his father and elder brothers would not listen and contradicted him. Zhao Yang captured Wu and imprisoned him in Jinyang. He then told the people of Handan, 'I have privately executed Wu. Whom do you gentlemen wish to establish as ruler?' He then killed Wu. Zhao Ji and She Bin rebelled, using Handan as their base. The lord of Jin sent Ji Qin to besiege Handan. Xun Yin and Fan Ji She were friendly with Wu. They were unwilling to help Qin and planned to rebel. Dong Anyu knew of this. In the tenth month, the Fan and Zhongxing clans attacked Zhao Yang. Yang fled to Jinyang, and the Jin people besieged him. Fan Ji She and Xun Yin's enemies, including Wei Xiang and others, planned to expel Xun Yin and replace him with Liang Yingfu; They expelled Ji She and replaced him with Fan Gaoxi. Xun Li spoke to the Marquis of Jin, saying, 'My lord commands that ministers who start rebellions die.' Now three ministers started the rebellion, but only Yang was expelled. The punishments are unequal. Please expel them all.' In the eleventh month, Xun Li, Han Bu Ning, and Wei Duo, following the duke's command, attacked the Fan and Zhongxing clans but did not succeed. The Fan and Zhongxing clans counterattacked the duke. The duke struck at them, and the Fan and Zhongxing clans were defeated and fled. On Ding Wei, the two sons fled to Zhao Ge. Han and Wei interceded on behalf of the Zhao clan. In the twelfth month on Xin Wei, Zhao Yang entered Jiang and formed an alliance in the duke's palace. The following year, Zhi Bo Wenzi told Zhao Yang, 'Although the Fan and Zhongxing clans truly rebelled, An Yu revealed it. This means An Yu was in on the plot.' Jin has a law: those who start rebellions die. Indeed, the two sons have already submitted to punishment, but An Yu alone remains.' Zhao Yang was worried about this. An Yu said, 'If I die, the Zhao clan will be settled and Jin will be pacified. My death comes too late.' He then committed suicide. The Zhao clan informed Zhi Bo, and then the Zhao clan was pacified.

Kong Zi heard that Zhao Jianzi executed Han Dan Wu without requesting the Jin lord's permission, and defended Jinyang. Therefore he wrote in the Chun Qiu: 'Zhao Yang rebelled with Jinyang.' Zhao Jianzi had a minister named Zhou She, who liked to remonstrate directly. After Zhou She died, Jianzi was often displeased whenever he listened to court. The grand masters requested punishment. Jianzi said, 'The grand masters have no crime.' I have heard that a thousand sheep skins are not equal to one fox's armpit. The grand masters at court only say 'yes, yes,' but I don't hear Zhou She's strong opinions. This is why I am worried.' Jianzi was thereby able to attach the Zhao cities and win over the Jin people.

In the eighteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Zhao Jianzi besieged the Fan and Zhongxing clans at Zhao Ge. Zhong Xing Wenzi fled to Handan. The following year, Duke Ling of Wei died. Jianzi and Yang Hu escorted Crown Prince Kuai Kui of Wei to Wei. Wei would not admit him, so he resided at Qi.

æ™‰å®šå…¬äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œç°¡å­æ‹”é‚¯é„²ï¼Œä¸­è¡Œæ–‡å­å¥”æŸäººã€‚ ç°¡å­åˆåœæŸäººï¼Œä¸­è¡Œæ–‡å­ã€èŒƒæ˜­å­é‚å¥”é½Šã€‚ è¶™ç«Ÿæœ‰é‚¯é„²ã€æŸäººã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œé¤˜é‚‘å…¥äºæ™‰ã€‚ è¶™åæ™‰å¿ï¼Œå¯¦å°ˆæ™‰æ¬Šï¼Œå¥‰é‚‘ä¾”æ–¼è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚
In the twenty-first year of Duke Ding of Jin, Jianzi captured Handan. Zhong Xing Wenzi fled to Bo Ren. Jianzi again besieged Bo Ren. Zhong Xing Wenzi and Fan Zhaozi then fled to Qi. Zhao finally possessed Handan and Bo Ren. The remaining cities of the Fan and Zhongxing clans were incorporated into Jin. Zhao was nominally a minister of Jin, but actually monopolized Jin's power. His fief cities equaled those of the feudal lords.

æ™‰å®šå…¬ä¸‰åå¹´ï¼Œå®šå…¬èˆ‡å³ç‹å¤«å·®çˆ­é•·æ–¼é»ƒæ± ï¼Œè¶™ç°¡å­å¾æ™‰å®šå…¬ï¼Œå’é•·å³ã€‚ å®šå…¬ä¸‰åä¸ƒå¹´å’ï¼Œè€Œç°¡å­é™¤ä¸‰å¹´ä¹‹å–ªï¼ŒæœŸè€Œå·²ã€‚ æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œè¶Šç‹å¥è¸æ»…å³ã€‚
In the thirtieth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Duke Ding contended for precedence with King Fu Chai of Wu at Huang Chi. Zhao Jianzi followed Duke Ding of Jin, and finally took precedence over Wu. Duke Ding died in his thirty-seventh year. Jianzi observed only one year of mourning instead of three. In this year, King Gou Jian of Yue extinguished Wu.

æ™‰å‡ºå…¬åä¸€å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯ä¼é„­ã€‚ è¶™ç°¡å­ç–¾ï¼Œä½¿å¤ªå­æ¯‹å¹å°‡è€Œåœé„­ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯é†‰ï¼Œä»¥é…’çŒæ“Šæ¯‹å¹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹ç¾¤è‡£è«‹æ­»ä¹‹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›æ‰€ä»¥ç½®æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œç‚ºèƒ½å¿ã€‚ã€ ç„¶äº¦æ…çŸ¥ä¼¯ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯æ­¸ï¼Œå› è¬‚ç°¡å­ï¼Œä½¿å»¢æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œç°¡å­ä¸è½ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹ç”±æ­¤æ€¨çŸ¥ä¼¯ã€‚
In the eleventh year of Duke Chu of Jin, Zhi Bo attacked Zheng. Zhao Jianzi was ill. He sent Crown Prince Wu Xu to lead troops and besiege Zheng. Zhi Bo was drunk. He poured wine on Wu Xu and struck him. Wu Xu's ministers requested to die for him. Wu Xu said, 'My lord placed me here because I can endure.' Yet he also resented Zhi Bo. Zhi Bo returned and therefore told Jianzi to abolish Wu Xu. Jianzi would not listen. Wu Xu resented Zhi Bo from this point on.

æ™‰å‡ºå…¬åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç°¡å­å’ï¼Œå¤ªå­æ¯‹å¹ä»£ç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºè¥„å­ã€‚
In the seventeenth year of Duke Chu of Jin, Jianzi died. Crown Prince Wu Xu succeeded him and stood as ruler. This was Xiangzi.

In the first year of Xiangzi of Zhao, Yue besieged Wu. Xiangzi lowered his mourning diet and sent Chu Long to inquire after the King of Wu.

è¥„å­å§Šå‰ç‚ºä»£ç‹å¤«äººã€‚ ç°¡å­æ—¢è‘¬ï¼Œæœªé™¤æœï¼ŒåŒ—ç™»å¤å±‹ï¼Œè«‹ä»£ç‹ã€‚ ä½¿å»šäººæ“éŠ…æ“ä»¥é£Ÿä»£ç‹åŠå¾è€…ï¼Œè¡Œæ–Ÿï¼Œé™°ä»¤å®°äººå„ä»¥æ“æ“Šæ®ºä»£ç‹åŠå¾å®˜ï¼Œé‚èˆˆå…µå¹³ä»£åœ°ã€‚ å…¶å§Šèä¹‹ï¼Œæ³£è€Œå‘¼å¤©ï¼Œæ‘©ç¬„è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ ä»£äººæ†ä¹‹ï¼Œæ‰€æ­»åœ°åä¹‹ç‚ºæ‘©ç¬„ä¹‹å±±ã€‚ é‚ä»¥ä»£å°ä¼¯é­¯å­å‘¨ç‚ºä»£æˆå›ã€‚ ä¼¯é­¯è€…ï¼Œè¥„å­å…„ï¼Œæ•…å¤ªå­ã€‚ å¤ªå­èš¤æ­»ï¼Œæ•…å°å…¶å­ã€‚
Xiangzi's sister had previously been the wife of the King of Dai. After Jianzi was buried but before mourning was removed, Xiangzi ascended the Xia Wu tower to the north and invited the King of Dai. He sent a cook holding a bronze dagger to serve food to the King of Dai and his followers. While pouring wine, he secretly commanded the butchers to each strike and kill the King of Dai and his following officials with their daggers. Then he raised troops to pacify Dai territory. When his sister heard of it, she wept and called to heaven, rubbed her hairpin, and committed suicide. The people of Dai pitied her. The place where she died was named Mo Ji Mountain. He then enfeoffed Bo Lu's son Zhou with Dai territory, making him Dai Cheng Jun. Bo Lu was Xiangzi's elder brother and former crown prince. The crown prince died early, so he enfeoffed his son.

è¥„å­ç«‹å››å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯èˆ‡è¶™ã€éŸ“ã€é­ç›¡åˆ†å…¶èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ•…åœ°ã€‚ æ™‰å‡ºå…¬æ€’ï¼Œå‘Šé½Šã€é­¯ï¼Œæ¬²ä»¥ä¼å››å¿ã€‚ å››å¿æï¼Œé‚å…±æ”»å‡ºå…¬ã€‚ å‡ºå…¬å¥”é½Šï¼Œé“æ­»ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯ä¹ƒç«‹æ˜­å…¬æ›¾å­«é©•ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ™‰æ‡¿å…¬ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯ç›Šé©•ã€‚ è«‹åœ°éŸ“ã€é­ï¼ŒéŸ“ã€é­èˆ‡ä¹‹ã€‚ è«‹åœ°è¶™ï¼Œè¶™ä¸èˆ‡ï¼Œä»¥å…¶åœé„­ä¹‹è¾±ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯æ€’ï¼Œé‚ç‡éŸ“ã€é­æ”»è¶™ã€‚ è¶™è¥„å­æ‡¼ï¼Œä¹ƒå¥”ä¿æ™‰é™½ã€‚
In the fourth year of Xiangzi's rule, Zhi Bo, along with Zhao, Han, and Wei, completely divided up the former territories of Fan and Zhongxing. Duke Chu of Jin was angry. He informed Qi and Lu, wishing to attack the four ministers. The four ministers were afraid, so they jointly attacked Duke Chu. Duke Chu fled to Qi and died en route. Zhi Bo then established Duke Zhao's great-grandson Jiao as ruler. This was Duke Yi of Jin. Zhi Bo grew increasingly arrogant. He requested territory from Han and Wei, and Han and Wei gave it to him. He requested territory from Zhao, but Zhao would not give it, because of the humiliation from the Zheng siege. Zhi Bo became angry and then led Han and Wei to attack Zhao. Zhao Xiangzi was afraid and fled to defend Jinyang.

åŸéå¾ï¼Œå¾Œï¼Œè‡³æ–¼ç‹æ¾¤ï¼Œè¦‹ä¸‰äººï¼Œè‡ªå¸¶ä»¥ä¸Šå¯è¦‹ï¼Œè‡ªå¸¶ä»¥ä¸‹ä¸å¯è¦‹ã€‚ èˆ‡åŸéç«¹äºŒç¯€ï¼Œè«é€šã€‚ æ›°ï¼šã€Œç‚ºæˆ‘ä»¥æ˜¯éºè¶™æ¯‹å¹ã€‚ã€ åŸéæ—¢è‡³ï¼Œä»¥å‘Šè¥„å­ã€‚ è¥„å­é½Šä¸‰æ—¥ï¼Œè¦ªè‡ªå‰–ç«¹ï¼Œæœ‰æœ±æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œä½™éœæ³°å±±å±±é™½ä¾¯å¤©ä½¿ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸‰æœˆä¸™æˆŒï¼Œä½™å°‡ä½¿å¥³åæ»…çŸ¥æ°ã€‚ å¥³äº¦ç«‹æˆ‘ç™¾é‚‘ï¼Œä½™å°‡è³œå¥³æ—èƒ¡ä¹‹åœ°ã€‚ è‡³äºå¾Œä¸–ï¼Œä¸”æœ‰ä¼‰ç‹ï¼Œèµ¤é»‘ï¼Œé¾é¢è€Œé³¥å™£ï¼Œé¬¢éº‹é«­é«¯ï¼Œå¤§è†ºå¤§èƒ¸ï¼Œä¿®ä¸‹è€Œé¦®ï¼Œå·¦è¢µç•Œä¹˜ï¼Œå¥„æœ‰æ²³å®—ï¼Œè‡³äºä¼‘æº·è«¸è²‰ï¼Œå—ä¼æ™‰åˆ¥ï¼ŒåŒ—æ»…é»‘å§‘ã€‚ã€ è¥„å­å†æ‹œï¼Œå—ä¸‰ç¥ä¹‹ä»¤ã€‚
Yuan Guo followed. Later, when they arrived at Wang Ze, he saw three persons. From the belt upward they were visible, but from the belt downward they were invisible. They gave Yuan Guo two bamboo joints, but he could not open them. They said, 'Send this to Zhao Wu Xu for me.' When Yuan Guo arrived, he told Xiangzi. Xiangzi purified himself for three days and personally split the bamboo. There was vermilion writing that said, 'Zhao Wu Xu, I am the heavenly envoy of Huo Tai Shan Shan Yang Hou.' On the Bing Xu day of the third month, I will make you counterattack and extinguish the Zhi clan.' You must also establish a hundred cities for me. I will grant you the territory of the Lin Hu.' In later generations, there will be a strong king, red and black in color, with a dragon's face and a bird's beak, deer-like temples and whiskers, a large breast and chest, long legs but bent, wearing left-lapelled robes and riding in a chariot. He will suddenly possess the River Ancestor, reaching to the Xiu Zhuo barbarians. He will attack the Jin branch to the south and extinguish the black aunt to the north.' Xiangzi bowed twice and received the command of the three spirits.

The three states attacked Jinyang. After more than a year, they diverted the Fen River to flood the city. The city was not submerged by three boards. In the city, they suspended cauldrons to cook and exchanged children to eat. All the ministers had disloyal hearts. The rituals became increasingly lax. Only Gao Gong dared not lose proper ritual. Xiangzi was afraid, so he secretly sent the prime minister Zhang Meng Tong to Han and Wei at night. Han and Wei united with him in plotting. On the Bing Xu day of the third month, the three states counterattacked and extinguished the Zhi clan, together dividing its territory. Thereupon Xiangzi distributed rewards, with Gao Gong receiving the highest. Zhang Meng Tong said, 'During the Jinyang crisis, only Gong had no merit.' Xiangzi said, 'When Jinyang was in crisis, all the ministers were lax. Only Gong dared not lose the ritual of a minister. This is why I put him first.' Thereupon Zhao possessed Dai to the north and annexed the Zhi clan to the south. It was stronger than Han and Wei. He then sacrificed to the three spirits at a hundred cities and sent Yuan Guo to preside over the sacrificial rites at Huo Tai Shan.

Later he married a woman from the Kong Tong clan and begat five sons. Lie Hou liked music. He told the prime minister Gong Zhong Lian, 'I have a favorite. Can I ennoble him?' Gong Zhong said, 'You can enrich him, but ennobling him would not be good.' Lie Hou said, 'Very well.' Indeed, the Zheng singers Qiang and Shi, two persons. I will grant them fields, ten thousand mu each.' Gong Zhong said, 'Very well.' He did not give it. After one month, Lie Hou came from Dai and asked about the singers' fields. Gong Zhong said, 'I sought them, but there were none suitable.' After a while, Lie Hou asked again. Gong Zhong finally refused. He claimed illness and did not attend court. The Lord of Fan Wu came from Dai and told Gong Zhong, 'You indeed love goodness, but you do not know what to hold to.' Now Gong Zhong has been prime minister of Zhao for four years. Have you also advanced any scholars?' Gong Zhong said, 'Not yet.' The Lord of Fan Wu said, 'Niu Xu, Xun Xin, and Xu Yue are all suitable.' Gong Zhong then advanced the three men. When they reached court, Lie Hou again asked, 'What about the singers' fields?' Gong Zhong said, 'I have just sent people to select the good ones.' Niu Xu served Lie Hou with benevolence and righteousness, constrained him with the kingly way, and Lie Hou was enlightened. The next day, Xun Xin served, selecting and training to raise the worthy, appointing officials and employing the able. The next day, Xu Yue served, regulating wealth and using frugality, examining and measuring merit and virtue. What was given was all sufficient. The lord was pleased. Lie Hou sent a messenger to tell the prime minister, 'The singers' fields should be stopped for now.' He appointed Niu Xu as teacher, Xun Xin as central captain, Xu Yue as inner scribe, and granted the prime minister two sets of clothes.

In the third year, they built city walls at Hao. In the fourth year, they met with Han at Qu Shu. In the fifth year, he married a woman from Han as his wife.

In the eighth year, Han attacked Qin but did not succeed and left. The five states mutually established each other as kings, but Zhao alone refused, saying, 'Without the substance, how dare I occupy the name!' He commanded the people of the state to call him 'jun'.

ä¹å¹´ï¼Œèˆ‡éŸ“ã€é­å…±æ“Šç§¦ï¼Œç§¦æ•—æˆ‘ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–å…«è¬ç´šã€‚ é½Šæ•—æˆ‘è§€æ¾¤ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å–æˆ‘ä¸­éƒ½åŠè¥¿é™½ã€‚ é½Šç ´ç‡•ã€‚ ç‡•ç›¸å­ä¹‹ç‚ºå›ï¼Œå›åç‚ºè‡£ã€‚ åä¸€å¹´ï¼Œç‹å¬å…¬å­è·æ–¼éŸ“ï¼Œç«‹ä»¥ç‚ºç‡•ç‹ï¼Œä½¿æ¨‚æ± é€ä¹‹ã€‚ åä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ‹”æˆ‘è—ºï¼Œè™œå°‡è»è¶™èŠã€‚ æ¥šã€é­ç‹ä¾†ï¼Œéé‚¯é„²ã€‚ åå››å¹´ï¼Œè¶™ä½•æ”»é­ã€‚
In the ninth year, they struck Qin together with Han and Wei. Qin defeated us and beheaded eighty thousand. Qi defeated us at Guan Ze. In the tenth year, Qin took our Zhong Du and Xi Yang. Qi broke Yan. Yan's prime minister Zi Zhi became the jun, and the jun became minister instead. In the eleventh year, the wang summoned Gong Zi Zhi from Han and established him as Yan wang, sending Le Chi to escort him. In the thirteenth year, Qin captured our Lin and captured General Zhao Zhuang. The kings of Chu and Wei came and passed through Handan. In the fourteenth year, Zhao He attacked Wei.

In the sixteenth year, King Hui of Qin died. The wang toured Da Ling. Another day, the wang dreamed he saw a maiden playing the zither and singing a poem that said, 'The beautiful person shines brightly, her face like the glory of the tiao flower.' Fate, ah fate, once there was no me Ying!' Another day, the wang drank wine and was happy. He repeatedly spoke of what he dreamed and imagined seeing her appearance. Wu Guang heard of it and, through the wife, admitted his daughter Wa Ying. Meng Yao also. Meng Yao was greatly favored by the wang. This was Hui Hou.

åå…«å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ­¦ç‹èˆ‡å­Ÿèªªèˆ‰é¾æ–‡èµ¤é¼ï¼Œçµ•è‡è€Œæ­»ã€‚ è¶™ç‹ä½¿ä»£ç›¸è¶™å›ºè¿å…¬å­ç¨·æ–¼ç‡•ï¼Œé€æ­¸ï¼Œç«‹ç‚ºç§¦ç‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ˜­ç‹ã€‚
In the eighteenth year, King Wu of Qin, with Meng Yue, lifted the dragon-patterned red tripod. His kneecap broke and he died. The king of Zhao sent the prime minister of Dai, Zhao Gu, to welcome Gong Zi Ji from Yan. He sent him back and established him as king of Qin. This was King Zhao.

åä¹å¹´æ˜¥æ­£æœˆï¼Œå¤§æœä¿¡å®®ã€‚ å¬è‚¥ç¾©èˆ‡è­°å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œäº”æ—¥è€Œç•¢ã€‚ ç‹åŒ—ç•¥ä¸­å±±ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œè‡³æ–¼æˆ¿å­ï¼Œé‚ä¹‹ä»£ï¼ŒåŒ—è‡³ç„¡çª®ï¼Œè¥¿è‡³æ²³ï¼Œç™»é»ƒè¯ä¹‹ä¸Šã€‚ å¬æ¨“ç·©è¬€æ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘å…ˆç‹å› ä¸–ä¹‹è®Šï¼Œä»¥é•·å—è—©ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå±¬é˜»æ¼³ã€æ»ä¹‹éšªï¼Œç«‹é•·åŸï¼Œåˆå–è—ºã€éƒ­ç‹¼ï¼Œæ•—æ—äººæ–¼èï¼Œè€ŒåŠŸæœªé‚ã€‚ ä»Šä¸­å±±åœ¨æˆ‘è…¹å¿ƒï¼ŒåŒ—æœ‰ç‡•ï¼Œæ±æœ‰èƒ¡ï¼Œè¥¿æœ‰æ—èƒ¡ã€æ¨“ç…©ã€ç§¦ã€éŸ“ä¹‹é‚Šï¼Œè€Œç„¡å½Šå…µä¹‹æ•‘ï¼Œæ˜¯äº¡ç¤¾ç¨·ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿ å¤«æœ‰é«˜ä¸–ä¹‹åï¼Œå¿…æœ‰éºä¿—ä¹‹ç´¯ã€‚ å¾æ¬²èƒ¡æœã€‚ã€ æ¨“ç·©æ›°ï¼šã€Œå–„ã€‚ã€ ç¾¤è‡£çš†ä¸æ¬²ã€‚
In the nineteenth year, spring, first month, great court at Xin Gong. He summoned Fei Yi to discuss the world with him. They finished in five days. The wang raided northward through Zhong Shan's territory, reaching Fang Zi. He then went to Dai, northward to infinity, westward to the river, and ascended Huang Hua above. He summoned Lou Huan to discuss and said, 'My former wang followed the world's changes to extend the southern border lands. He connected to the dangers of the Zhang and Fu rivers, established a long wall, also took Lin and Guo Lang, defeated the Lin people at Ren, but the merit was not completed.' Now Zhong Shan is in my heartland. To the north is Yan, to the east is Hu, to the west are the borders of Lin Hu, Lou Fan, Qin, and Han, but there are no strong troops to rescue. This will perish the state altars. What to do?' Indeed, one who has a reputation surpassing the world must bear the burden of departing from custom. I wish to adopt barbarian clothing.' Lou Huan said, 'Good.' All the ministers did not wish it.

æ–¼æ˜¯è‚¥ç¾©ä¾ï¼Œç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œç°¡ã€è¥„ä¸»ä¹‹çƒˆï¼Œè¨ˆèƒ¡ã€ç¿Ÿä¹‹åˆ©ã€‚ ç‚ºäººè‡£è€…ï¼Œå¯µæœ‰å­å¼Ÿé•·å¹¼é †æ˜ä¹‹ç¯€ï¼Œé€šæœ‰è£œæ°‘ç›Šä¸»ä¹‹æ¥­ï¼Œæ­¤å…©è€…è‡£ä¹‹åˆ†ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå¾æ¬²ç¹¼è¥„ä¸»ä¹‹è·¡ï¼Œé–‹æ–¼èƒ¡ã€ç¿Ÿä¹‹é„‰ï¼Œè€Œå’ä¸–ä¸è¦‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‚ºæ•µå¼±ï¼Œç”¨åŠ›å°‘è€ŒåŠŸå¤šï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ¯‹ç›¡ç™¾å§“ä¹‹å‹ï¼Œè€Œåºå¾€å¤ä¹‹å‹³ã€‚ å¤«æœ‰é«˜ä¸–ä¹‹åŠŸè€…ï¼Œè² éºä¿—ä¹‹ç´¯ï¼› æœ‰ç¨æ™ºä¹‹æ…®è€…ï¼Œä»»é©æ°‘ä¹‹æ€¨ã€‚ ä»Šå¾å°‡èƒ¡æœé¨å°„ä»¥æ•™ç™¾å§“ï¼Œè€Œä¸–å¿…è­°å¯¡äººï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£èç–‘äº‹ç„¡åŠŸï¼Œç–‘è¡Œç„¡åã€‚ ç‹æ—¢å®šè² éºä¿—ä¹‹æ…®ï¼Œæ®†ç„¡é¡§å¤©ä¸‹ä¹‹è­°çŸ£ã€‚ å¤«è«–è‡³å¾·è€…ä¸å’Œæ–¼ä¿—ï¼Œæˆå¤§åŠŸè€…ä¸è¬€æ–¼çœ¾ã€‚ æ˜”è€…èˆœèˆæœ‰è‹—ï¼Œç¦¹è¢’è£¸åœ‹ï¼Œéä»¥é¤Šæ¬²è€Œæ¨‚å¿—ä¹Ÿï¼Œå‹™ä»¥è«–å¾·è€Œç´„åŠŸä¹Ÿã€‚ æ„šè€…é—‡æˆäº‹ï¼Œæ™ºè€…ç¹æœªå½¢ï¼Œå‰‡ç‹ä½•ç–‘ç„‰ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾ä¸ç–‘èƒ¡æœä¹Ÿï¼Œå¾æå¤©ä¸‹ç¬‘æˆ‘ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‹‚å¤«ä¹‹æ¨‚ï¼Œæ™ºè€…å“€ç„‰ï¼› æ„šè€…æ‰€ç¬‘ï¼Œè³¢è€…å¯Ÿç„‰ã€‚ ä¸–æœ‰é †æˆ‘è€…ï¼Œèƒ¡æœä¹‹åŠŸæœªå¯çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ é›–é©…ä¸–ä»¥ç¬‘æˆ‘ï¼Œèƒ¡åœ°ä¸­å±±å¾å¿…æœ‰ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é‚èƒ¡æœçŸ£ã€‚
Thereupon Fei Yi served. The wang said, 'The achievements of Lords Jian and Xiang, planning the benefits of the Hu and Di.' For those who are ministers, when favored they have the principles of filial piety, fraternal duty, respecting elders and juniors, obedience and clarity. In general, they have achievements that benefit the people and benefit the lord. These two are the minister's duty. Now I wish to continue Lord Xiang's traces, opening to the regions of the Hu and Di, but for generations they have not seen it. It makes enemies weak. It uses little strength but achieves much merit. It can avoid exhausting the commoners' labor and continue the merits of past ancients. Indeed, those who have merit surpassing the world bear the burden of departing from custom; Those who have uniquely wise considerations bear the resentment of stubborn people. Now I will teach the commoners barbarian clothing and horse archery, but the world will surely criticize me. What to do?' Fei Yi said, 'I have heard that doubtful matters achieve no merit, and doubtful actions achieve no reputation.' The wang had already decided to bear the considerations of departing from custom. He nearly had no regard for the world's criticisms. Indeed, those who discuss utmost virtue do not harmonize with custom. Those who complete great merit do not plan with the masses. Formerly, Shun danced for You Miao, Yu went bare in the naked state. It was not to nurture desires and please the will. He strove to discuss virtue and summarize merit. Foolish ones complete matters in the dark. Wise ones see what has not yet formed. So what does the wang doubt?' The wang said, 'I do not doubt the barbarian clothing. I fear the world will laugh at me.' The mad husband's joy, the wise ones grieve over it; What foolish ones laugh at, worthy ones examine. If the world has those who follow me, the merit of barbarian clothing cannot yet be known. Although it drives the world to laugh at me, I must have the barbarian lands and Zhong Shan.' Thereupon he then adopted barbarian clothing.

He sent Wang Xi to Gong Zi Cheng, saying, 'I have adopted barbarian clothing and will use it for court audiences. I also wish for you, uncle, to wear it.' The family obeys parents and the state obeys the lord. This is the common practice of ancient and present times. A son does not oppose his parents. A minister does not defy his lord. This is the common righteousness among brothers. Now I create a teaching to change clothing, but if uncle does not wear it, I fear the world will criticize it. Governing the state has constants. Benefiting the people is the foundation; Following governance has its classics. Commands and actions are superior. Bright virtue is first discussed among the lowly, but governing affairs first requires trustworthiness among the noble. The intention of barbarian clothing now is not to nurture desires and please the will; Matters have a stopping place and merit has a coming out. When matters succeed and are established, then it is good. Now I fear uncle will oppose following the classics of governance, to help uncle's discussions. Moreover, I have heard that matters that benefit the state have actions without crookedness. Those who rely on noble relatives have reputations that are not burdened. Hence I wish to admire the righteousness of Duke Uncle to complete the merit of barbarian clothing. Have Xi visit uncle and request that he wear it.' Gong Zi Cheng bowed twice and knocked his head, saying, 'Your minister has indeed heard of the wang's barbarian clothing.' Your minister is not talented. He has a bed illness and is unable to hasten and run to moreover advance. The wang commands it. Your minister dares to respond and thus exhausts his foolish loyalty. He said, 'Your minister has heard that China is indeed where clever understanding and obedient wisdom reside, where the wealth and use of myriad things gather, where worthy sages teach, where benevolence and righteousness are applied, where poems, books, rites, and music are used, where different clever skills are tested, where distant places observe and hasten to, and where barbarians and yi practice righteousness.' Now the wang abandons this and follows the clothing of distant places, changes ancient teachings, alters the ways of ancient people, opposes people's hearts, frustrates scholars, and separates China. Hence your minister wishes the wang to plan it.' The messenger reported this. The wang said, 'I have indeed heard of uncle's illness. I will personally go to invite him.'

The wang then went to Gong Zi Cheng's home and thus personally invited him, saying, 'Indeed, clothing is what makes use convenient;' Rites are what make matters convenient. Sage people observe regions and follow what is suitable. They establish rites according to matters. This is what benefits their people and enriches their state. Indeed, cutting hair and tattooing bodies, tattooing arms and left lapels - these are the people of Ou Yue. Black teeth and carved foreheads, reversed crowns and grain sashes - these are the state of Great Wu. Hence rites and clothing are not the same. Their convenience is one. Regions are different and use changes. Matters are different and rites alter. This is why sage people, if they can benefit their state, do not unify their use; If it can make their matters convenient, do not make their rites the same. Ru scholars have one teacher but customs are different. China has the same rites but teachings are separate. Moreover, what about the convenience of mountains and valleys? Hence the changes of leaving and taking, wise ones cannot unify; The clothing of far and near, worthy sages cannot make the same. Remote regions have many differences. Crooked learning has many arguments. Those who do not know but do not doubt, those who are different from themselves but do not criticize - these are public and the masses seek complete goodness. What uncle speaks of now is custom. What I speak of is what governs custom. My state to the east has the waters of the river and Bo Luo. It shares them with Qi and Zhong Shan. There is no use for boats and oars. From Chang Shan to Dai and Shang Dang, to the east are the borders of Yan and Dong Hu, and to the west are the borders of Lou Fan, Qin, and Han. Now there are no preparations for horse archery. Hence I have no use for boats and oars. The people who dwell between the waters - how will they guard the waters of the river and Bo Luo? Change clothing and horse archery to prepare for the borders of Yan, the three Hu, Qin, and Han. Moreover, formerly Lord Jian did not block Jin Yang and reach Shang Dang, but Lord Xiang annexed the Rong and Dai to expel the various Hu. This is what foolish and wise both understand. Previously, Zhong Shan relied on Qi's strong troops, invaded and ravaged my lands, bound and burdened my people, led water to surround Xiang. Had it not been for the spirits of the state altars, Xiang would nearly not have been guarded. The former wang hated it, but the resentment has not yet been repaid. Now preparations for horse archery - near they can make convenient Shang Dang's terrain, and far they can repay Zhong Shan's resentment. But uncle follows China's customs to oppose the intentions of Jian and Xiang, hates the name of changing clothing to forget the shame of the Xiang matter. This is not what I hope for.' Gong Zi Cheng bowed twice and knocked his head, saying, 'Your minister is foolish and does not reach the wang's righteousness. I dared to speak of what the world customarily hears. This is my minister's crime.' Now the wang will continue the intentions of Jian and Xiang to follow the former wang's will. How dare your minister not listen to the command!' He bowed twice and knocked his head. Then he granted barbarian clothing. The next day, he wore it and attended court. Thereupon he began to issue the barbarian clothing command.

Zhao Wen, Zhao Zao, Zhou Shan, and Zhao Jun all advised to stop the wang from barbarian clothing, saying the old laws were convenient. The king remarked: 'Former kings followed different customsâ€”what ancient laws are there to follow?' Emperors and kings do not copy one anotherâ€”what rituals should we adhere to? Fuxi and Shennong taught their people without resorting to punishment; the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun administered punishment without personal anger. By the time of the Three Kings, they crafted laws to suit the era and established rituals to fit the situation. Laws, standards, decrees, and commands each conformed to what was proper; clothing and tools each served their practical purpose. Therefore, ritual need not follow a single path, and what benefits the state need not derive from ancient precedent. The sages rose to power without imitating their predecessors; the Xia and Yin dynasties fell without changing their rituals. Thus, reverting to ancient ways cannot be condemned, but merely following ritual traditions is not worthy of great praise. Moreover, those who wear outlandish clothing harbor licentious ambitions, but that would mean Zou and Lu produce no men of exceptional character; Eccentric customs make the people fickle, but that would mean Wu and Yue produce no outstanding scholars. Moreover, the sages defined 'clothing' as what benefits the body, and 'ritual' as what facilitates affairs. Indeed, the rules governing advancement and withdrawal, the regulations for clothingâ€”these serve to discipline the common people, not to evaluate the worthy. Therefore, guide the people to follow prevailing customs, while the worthy adapt to changing circumstances. Hence the proverb: 'He who drives a horse according to the book fails to grasp the horse's true nature; he who applies ancient systems to modern times fails to understand how circumstances change.' Merely following established laws does not elevate one above the common world; Merely studying ancient precedents does not equip one to govern the present day. You are not up to the task.' Thus he adopted barbarian attire and recruited mounted archers.

In the twentieth year, the king conquered Zhongshan lands as far as Ningjia; To the west, he conquered barbarian territory as far as Yuzhong. The king of Linhu presented horses as tribute. Upon his return, he dispatched Lou Huan to Qin, Qiu Ye to Han, Wang Ben to Chu, Fu Ding to Wei, and Zhao Jue to Qi. Zhao Gu, chancellor of Dai, took command of the barbarians and brought their forces.

äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œæ”»ä¸­å±±ã€‚ è¶™è¢‘ç‚ºå³è»ï¼Œè¨±éˆç‚ºå·¦è»ï¼Œå…¬å­ç« ç‚ºä¸­è»ï¼Œç‹å¹¶å°‡ä¹‹ã€‚ ç‰›ç¿¦å°‡è»Šé¨ï¼Œè¶™å¸Œå¹¶å°‡èƒ¡ã€ä»£ã€‚ è¶™èˆ‡ä¹‹é™˜ï¼Œåˆè»æ›²é™½ï¼Œæ”»å–ä¸¹ä¸˜ã€è¯é™½ã€é´Ÿä¹‹å¡ã€‚ ç‹è»å–é„—ã€çŸ³é‚‘ã€å°é¾ã€æ±å£ã€‚ ä¸­å±±ç»å››é‚‘å’Œï¼Œç‹è¨±ä¹‹ï¼Œç½·å…µã€‚ äºŒåä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ”»ä¸­å±±ã€‚ äºŒåäº”å¹´ï¼Œæƒ åå’ã€‚ ä½¿å‘¨è¢‘èƒ¡æœå‚…ç‹å­ä½•ã€‚ äºŒåå…­å¹´ï¼Œå¾©æ”»ä¸­å±±ï¼Œæ”˜åœ°åŒ—è‡³ç‡•ã€ä»£ï¼Œè¥¿è‡³é›²ä¸­ã€ä¹åŸã€‚
In the twenty-first year, he attacked Zhongshan. Zhao Fen commanded the right army, Xu Hun the left army, Prince Zhang the center army, with Wang Bing as overall commander. Niu Jian commanded the chariots and cavalry, while Zhao Xi commanded the barbarian and Dai forces. The army rendezvoused at Zhi Gorge, assembled at Quyang, and attacked and captured Danqiu, Huayang, and Chi Pass. The king's army captured Xiang, Shiyi, Fenglong, and Dongyuan. Zhongshan offered four cities to make peace; the king accepted and disbanded his army. In the twenty-third year, he attacked Zhongshan again. In the twenty-fifth year, Empress Hui passed away. He ordered Zhou Fen to wear barbarian attire while tutoring Prince He. In the twenty-sixth year, he attacked Zhongshan again, extending Zhao's borders north to Yan and Dai, west to Yunzhong and Jiuyuan.

äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´äº”æœˆæˆŠç”³ï¼Œå¤§æœæ–¼æ±å®®ï¼Œå‚³åœ‹ï¼Œç«‹ç‹å­ä½•ä»¥ç‚ºç‹ã€‚ ç‹å»Ÿè¦‹ç¦®ç•¢ï¼Œå‡ºè‡¨æœã€‚ å¤§å¤«æ‚‰ç‚ºè‡£ï¼Œè‚¥ç¾©ç‚ºç›¸åœ‹ï¼Œå¹¶å‚…ç‹ã€‚ æ˜¯ç‚ºæƒ æ–‡ç‹ã€‚ æƒ æ–‡ç‹ï¼Œæƒ åå³å¨ƒå­ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ­¦éˆç‹è‡ªè™Ÿç‚ºä¸»çˆ¶ã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, on the wushen day of the fifth month, he held a grand court assembly in the Eastern Palace, ceded the throne, and installed Prince He as king. After completing the rites at the ancestral temple, the king emerged to hold audience. All the grandees became his ministers, Fei Yi was appointed chancellor and also served as the king's tutor. He became known as King Huiwen. King Huiwen was Empress Hui's son by a woman from Wu. King Wuling took the title 'Lord Father' for himself.

ä¸»çˆ¶æ¬²ä»¤å­ä¸»æ²»åœ‹ï¼Œè€Œèº«èƒ¡æœå°‡å£«å¤§å¤«è¥¿åŒ—ç•¥èƒ¡åœ°ï¼Œè€Œæ¬²å¾é›²ä¸­ã€ä¹åŸç›´å—è¥²ç§¦ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯è©è‡ªç‚ºä½¿è€…å…¥ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦æ˜­ç‹ä¸çŸ¥ï¼Œå·²è€Œæ€ªå…¶ç‹€ç”šå‰ï¼Œéäººè‡£ä¹‹åº¦ï¼Œä½¿äººé€ä¹‹ï¼Œè€Œä¸»çˆ¶é¦³å·²è„«é—œçŸ£ã€‚ å¯©å•ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒä¸»çˆ¶ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç§¦äººå¤§é©šã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶æ‰€ä»¥å…¥ç§¦è€…ï¼Œæ¬²è‡ªç•¥åœ°å½¢ï¼Œå› è§€ç§¦ç‹ä¹‹ç‚ºäººä¹Ÿã€‚
Lord Father wished his son to govern the state while he himself, clad in barbarian attire, led the nobles northwest to conquer barbarian territories, intending to strike south directly from Yunzhong and Jiuyuan to attack Qin. Thus he disguised himself as an envoy and infiltrated Qin. King Zhao of Qin did not recognize him at first, but soon noted his extraordinarily dignified bearing, quite unlike that of a mere subject. He sent men to pursue him, but Lord Father had already galloped away and escaped through the pass. Upon thorough investigation, they discovered it was Lord Father. The Qin court was stunned. Lord Father's purpose in entering Qin was to personally reconnoiter the terrain and assess King Zhao's character.

In King Huiwen's second year, Lord Father inspected the newly conquered lands, then departed from Dai and encountered the king of Loufan to the west at the Xi River, securing his military support.

ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ»…ä¸­å±±ï¼Œé·å…¶ç‹æ–¼è†šæ–½ã€‚ èµ·éˆå£½ï¼ŒåŒ—åœ°æ–¹å¾ï¼Œä»£é“å¤§é€šã€‚ é‚„æ­¸ï¼Œè¡Œè³ï¼Œå¤§èµ¦ï¼Œç½®é…’é…ºäº”æ—¥ï¼Œå°é•·å­ç« ç‚ºä»£å®‰é™½å›ã€‚ ç« ç´ ä¾ˆï¼Œå¿ƒä¸æœå…¶å¼Ÿæ‰€ç«‹ã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶åˆä½¿ç”°ä¸ç¦®ç›¸ç« ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the third year, he annihilated Zhongshan and exiled its king to Fushi. He established Lingshou; the northern territories submitted; the road to Dai was greatly improved. Upon his return, he distributed rewards, declared a general amnesty, held drinking banquets for five days, and enfeoffed his eldest son Zhang as Lord of Dai Anyang. Zhang was habitually extravagant and could not accept in his heart that his younger brother had been made king. Lord Father also appointed Tian Buli as chancellor to Zhang.

æå…Œè¬‚è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…¬å­ç« å½Šå£¯è€Œå¿—é©•ï¼Œé»¨çœ¾è€Œæ¬²å¤§ï¼Œæ®†æœ‰ç§ä¹ï¼Ÿ ç”°ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹ç‚ºäººä¹Ÿï¼Œå¿æ®ºè€Œé©•ã€‚ äºŒäººç›¸å¾—ï¼Œå¿…æœ‰è¬€é™°è³Šèµ·ï¼Œä¸€å‡ºèº«å¾¼å¹¸ã€‚ å¤«å°äººæœ‰æ¬²ï¼Œè¼•æ…®æ·ºè¬€ï¼Œå¾’è¦‹å…¶åˆ©è€Œä¸é¡§å…¶å®³ï¼ŒåŒé¡ç›¸æ¨ï¼Œä¿±å…¥ç¦é–€ã€‚ ä»¥å¾è§€ä¹‹ï¼Œå¿…ä¸ä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ å­ä»»é‡è€Œå‹¢å¤§ï¼Œäº‚ä¹‹æ‰€å§‹ï¼Œç¦ä¹‹æ‰€é›†ä¹Ÿï¼Œå­å¿…å…ˆæ‚£ã€‚ ä»è€…æ„›è¬ç‰©è€Œæ™ºè€…å‚™ç¦æ–¼æœªå½¢ï¼Œä¸ä»ä¸æ™ºï¼Œä½•ä»¥ç‚ºåœ‹ï¼Ÿ å­å¥šä¸ç¨±ç–¾æ¯‹å‡ºï¼Œå‚³æ”¿æ–¼å…¬å­æˆï¼Ÿ æ¯‹ç‚ºæ€¨åºœï¼Œæ¯‹ç‚ºç¦æ¢¯ã€‚ã€ è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ï¼Œæ˜”è€…ä¸»çˆ¶ä»¥ç‹å±¬ç¾©ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€æ¯‹è®Šè€Œåº¦ï¼Œæ¯‹ç•°è€Œæ…®ï¼Œå …å®ˆä¸€å¿ƒï¼Œä»¥æ­¿è€Œä¸–ã€‚ã€ ç¾©å†æ‹œå—å‘½è€Œç±ä¹‹ã€‚ ä»Šç•ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹é›£è€Œå¿˜å¾ç±ï¼Œè®Šå­°å¤§ç„‰ã€‚ é€²å—åš´å‘½ï¼Œé€€è€Œä¸å…¨ï¼Œè² å­°ç”šç„‰ã€‚ è®Šè² ä¹‹è‡£ï¼Œä¸å®¹æ–¼åˆ‘ã€‚ è«ºæ›°ã€æ­»è€…å¾©ç”Ÿï¼Œç”Ÿè€…ä¸æ„§ã€ã€‚ å¾è¨€å·²åœ¨å‰çŸ£ï¼Œå¾æ¬²å…¨å¾è¨€ï¼Œå®‰å¾—å…¨å¾èº«ï¼ ä¸”å¤«è²è‡£ä¹Ÿé›£è‡³è€Œç¯€è¦‹ï¼Œå¿ è‡£ä¹Ÿç´¯è‡³è€Œè¡Œæ˜ã€‚ å­å‰‡æœ‰è³œè€Œå¿ æˆ‘çŸ£ï¼Œé›–ç„¶ï¼Œå¾æœ‰èªåœ¨å‰è€…ä¹Ÿï¼Œçµ‚ä¸æ•¢å¤±ã€‚ã€ æå…Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œè«¾ï¼Œå­å‹‰ä¹‹çŸ£ï¼ å¾è¦‹å­å·²ä»Šå¹´è€³ã€‚ã€ æ¶•æ³£è€Œå‡ºã€‚ æå…Œæ•¸è¦‹å…¬å­æˆï¼Œä»¥å‚™ç”°ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹äº‹ã€‚
Li Kui said to Fei Yi: 'Prince Zhang is strong and vigorous but arrogant in his ambitions, commands many followers and harbors grand designsâ€”does he perhaps have ulterior motives?' Tian Buli is a man who tolerates murder and acts with arrogance. The two men are well-matched; dark and treacherous schemes are sure to arise between them, each seeking personal gain through desperate gambles. Indeed, petty men are driven by desires, their plans shallow and their schemes superficial. They see only the benefits without considering the harms, pushing each other along like their kind, all stumbling through the gate of disaster. In my judgment, disaster cannot be far off. You bear heavy responsibilities and wield great powerâ€”you are the source of disorder, the gathering point of calamity. You will surely be the first to suffer. The benevolent cherish all living things; the wise prepare for disaster before it manifests. Without benevolence or wisdom, how can one govern a state? Why not feign illness and withdraw from court, handing over governance to Prince Cheng? Do not become a storehouse of resentment, nor a ladder for disaster.' Fei Yi replied: 'It cannot be done. Lord Father once entrusted the king to my care, saying: "Do not alter your principles, do not harbor divided thoughts, hold steadfast to one purpose, unto death and throughout the ages."' Fei Yi bowed twice, accepted the charge, and committed it to writing. Now, to fear Buli's threats and forget my written pledgeâ€”what greater betrayal could there be? Having stepped forward to accept solemn commands, but retreating without fulfilling themâ€”what greater disloyalty could there be? A minister who reneges on his commitments cannot be tolerated, even by the harshest punishments. As the proverb says: 'The dead are brought back to life, the living have no cause for shame.' My words have already been spoken; I wish to honor them completely. How can I preserve my body if I do not? Moreover, the steadfast minister reveals his integrity when hardships come; the loyal minister demonstrates his virtue when troubles multiply. You have already honored me with your wisdom and shown me loyalty. Nevertheless, I have given my word before, and I dare not ultimately forsake it.' Li Kui replied: 'Very well, then exert yourself!' 'I will see you again before this year is out.' Weeping, he departed. Li Kui met frequently with Prince Cheng to prepare against Tian Buli's schemes.

On another day, Fei Yi said to Xin Qi: 'The prince and Tian Buli are extremely troubling.' In matters of righteousness, he has a reputation for goodness but a reality of evil. Such a person is neither a proper son nor a proper minister. I have heard it said that when treacherous ministers fill the court, it spells ruin for the state; Slanderers in the inner circle are parasites gnawing at their ruler. This man is greedy and ambitious, currying favor within while tyrannizing without. It is no great feat to forge orders and show disrespect, monopolizing power for a single dayâ€”but such calamity will engulf the entire state. Now I worry over it so much that at night I forget to sleep, and when hungry I forget to eat. We must prepare against bandits and traitors coming and going. From this day forward, anyone summoning the king must first face me. I will personally stand in their way; only if there is no treachery may the king enter.' Xin Qi exclaimed: 'Excellent! I am privileged to hear such wisdom!'

In the fourth year, he received the ministers at court; the Lord of Anyang also attended. Lord Father had the king preside over court while he observed from the sidelines, scrutinizing the etiquette of ministers and royal kin. Seeing his eldest son Zhang standing there dejected, facing north as a subject and deferring to his younger brother, Lord Father felt pity in his heart. Thus he considered dividing Zhao and making Zhang king of Dai, but the plan remained unresolved and was set aside.

Lord Father and the king traveled to Shaqiu, lodging in separate palaces. Prince Zhang immediately rebelled with his followers and Tian Buli, falsely summoning the king under Lord Father's name. Fei Yi rushed in first and slew them. Gao Xin immediately engaged the king in battle. Prince Cheng and Li Kui arrived from the capital, raised troops from four cities to confront the crisis, slew Prince Zhang and Tian Buli, exterminated their traitorous partisans, and restored order to the royal house. Prince Cheng was appointed chancellor and given the title Lord of Anping; Li Kui became the judicial minister. When Prince Zhang was defeated, he fled to Lord Father, who admitted him. But then Prince Cheng and Li Kui surrounded Lord Father's palace. After Prince Zhang's death, Prince Cheng and Li Kui conferred: 'We besieged Lord Father because of Zhang. If we lift the siege now, we will all be executed.' Thus they maintained the siege on Lord Father. They commanded the palace attendants: 'Whoever emerges last will be executed.' All the attendants emerged. Lord Father wished to leave but could not, nor could he obtain food. He scraped clay from the cups and ate it. After more than three months, he starved to death in the Shaqiu palace. Once Lord Father's death was confirmed, they declared mourning and notified the other feudal lords.

At this time the king was young; Prince Cheng and Li Kui held all power and, fearing execution, maintained their siege of Lord Father. (After Lord Father's death and King Huiwen's ascension) In the fifth year, Zhao exchanged territory with Yan: Dan and Yi. In the eighth year, he fortified the city of Xing Tang in the south. He met with Qin forces at Zhongyang. In the fifteenth year, King Zhao of Yan paid a visit. Zhao joined Han, Wei, and Qin in attacking Qi. The King of Qi fled in defeat, but Yan alone pressed deep into enemy territory and captured Linzi.

Now your lordship's virtuous deeds and meritorious exertions are not frequently directed toward Qin; The poisonous resentment and accumulated anger are not deeply rooted in Qi from ancient times. Qin and Zhao are allied states, yet Qin uses its power to conscript troops from Hanâ€”does Qin truly cherish Zhao? Or does Qin actually despise Qi? The wise ruler examines matters that go to extremes. Qin does not love Zhao and hate Qi; it seeks to destroy Han and devour the two Zhou states, using Qi as bait to lure the world. Fearing their plans might fail, they sent troops to intimidate Wei and Zhao. Fearing the world would grow wary of them, they offered hostages as tokens of good faith. In the twenty-first year, Zhao diverted the Zhang River west of Wuping. In the twenty-second year, a major epidemic struck. Prince Dan was established as crown prince.

In the twenty-third year, Lou Chang commanded the attack on Wei's Ji but failed to capture it. In the twelfth month, Lian Po commanded the attack on Ji and captured it. In the twenty-fourth year, Lian Po commanded the attack on Wei's Fangzi, captured it, fortified the position, and returned. He then attacked Anyang and captured it. In the twenty-fifth year, Yan Zhou commanded the attack on Changcheng and Gaotang and captured them. Together with Wei, they attacked Qin. Qin's general Bai Qi defeated our forces at Huayang and captured one of our generals. In the twenty-sixth year, Zhao conquered Eastern Hu territories as far as Ou and Dai.

In the twenty-seventh year, the Zhang River was diverted south of Wuping. Zhao Bao was enfeoffed as Lord of Pingyang. The Yellow River overflowed, causing major flooding.

In the twenty-eighth year, Lin Xiangru attacked Qi and advanced as far as Pingyi. Construction was abandoned on the great city north of Jiu Gate. Yan's general, Lord Cheng'an Gongsun Cao, assassinated his king. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin and Han attacked each other and jointly besieged Yan and Yu. Zhao sent Zhao She to command the attack on Qin. He decisively defeated the Qin army below Yan and Yu and was granted the title Lord Ma Fu.

In the thirty-third year, King Huiwen died. Crown Prince Dan ascended the throne as King Xiaocheng.

å­æˆç‹å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦ä¼æˆ‘ï¼Œæ‹”ä¸‰åŸã€‚ è¶™ç‹æ–°ç«‹ï¼Œå¤ªåç”¨äº‹ï¼Œç§¦æ€¥æ”»ä¹‹ã€‚ è¶™æ°æ±‚æ•‘æ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¿…ä»¥é•·å®‰å›ç‚ºè³ªï¼Œå…µä¹ƒå‡ºã€‚ã€ å¤ªåä¸è‚¯ï¼Œå¤§è‡£å½Šè««ã€‚ å¤ªåæ˜è¬‚å·¦å³æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾©è¨€é•·å®‰å›ç‚ºè³ªè€…ï¼Œè€å©¦å¿…å”¾å…¶é¢ã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«è§¸é¾è¨€é¡˜è¦‹å¤ªåï¼Œå¤ªåç››æ°£è€Œèƒ¥ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¥ï¼Œå¾è¶¨è€Œåï¼Œè‡ªè¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£ç—…è¶³ï¼Œæ›¾ä¸èƒ½ç–¾èµ°ï¼Œä¸å¾—è¦‹ä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ ç«Šè‡ªæ•ï¼Œè€Œæå¤ªåé«”ä¹‹æœ‰æ‰€è‹¦ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…é¡˜æœ›è¦‹å¤ªåã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦æƒè¼¦è€Œè¡Œè€³ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œé£Ÿå¾—æ¯‹è¡°ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæƒç²¥è€³ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£é–’è€…æ®Šä¸æ¬²é£Ÿï¼Œä¹ƒå½Šæ­¥ï¼Œæ—¥ä¸‰å››é‡Œï¼Œå°‘ç›Šå—œé£Ÿï¼Œå’Œæ–¼èº«ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦ä¸èƒ½ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåä¸å’Œä¹‹è‰²å°‘è§£ã€‚ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£è³¤æ¯èˆ’ç¥ºæœ€å°‘ï¼Œä¸è‚–ï¼Œè€Œè‡£è¡°ï¼Œç«Šæ†æ„›ä¹‹ï¼Œé¡˜å¾—è£œé»‘è¡£ä¹‹ç¼ºä»¥è¡›ç‹å®®ï¼Œæ˜§æ­»ä»¥èã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•¬è«¾ã€‚ å¹´å¹¾ä½•çŸ£ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œåäº”æ­²çŸ£ã€‚ é›–å°‘ï¼Œé¡˜åŠæœªå¡«æºå£‘è€Œè¨—ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸ˆå¤«äº¦æ„›æ†å°‘å­ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œç”šæ–¼å©¦äººã€‚ã€ å¤ªåç¬‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œå©¦äººç•°ç”šã€‚ã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£ç«Šä»¥ç‚ºåª¼ä¹‹æ„›ç‡•åè³¢æ–¼é•·å®‰å›ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œå›éçŸ£ï¼Œä¸è‹¥é•·å®‰å›ä¹‹ç”šã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œçˆ¶æ¯æ„›å­å‰‡ç‚ºä¹‹è¨ˆæ·±é ã€‚ åª¼ä¹‹é€ç‡•åä¹Ÿï¼ŒæŒå…¶è¸µï¼Œç‚ºä¹‹æ³£ï¼Œå¿µå…¶é ä¹Ÿï¼Œäº¦å“€ä¹‹çŸ£ã€‚ å·²è¡Œï¼Œéä¸æ€ä¹Ÿï¼Œç¥­ç¥€å‰‡ç¥ä¹‹æ›°ã€å¿…å‹¿ä½¿åã€ï¼Œè±ˆéè¨ˆé•·ä¹…ï¼Œç‚ºå­å­«ç›¸ç¹¼ç‚ºç‹ä¹Ÿå“‰ï¼Ÿã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¶ã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä¸‰ä¸–ä»¥å‰ï¼Œè‡³æ–¼è¶™ä¸»ä¹‹å­å­«ç‚ºä¾¯è€…ï¼Œå…¶ç¹¼æœ‰åœ¨è€…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡æœ‰ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾®ç¨è¶™ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æœ‰åœ¨è€…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦ä¸èä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å…¶è¿‘è€…ç¦åŠå…¶èº«ï¼Œé è€…åŠå…¶å­å­«ã€‚ è±ˆäººä¸»ä¹‹å­ä¾¯å‰‡ä¸å–„å“‰ï¼Ÿ ä½å°Šè€Œç„¡åŠŸï¼Œå¥‰åšè€Œç„¡å‹ï¼Œè€ŒæŒ¾é‡å™¨å¤šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šåª¼å°Šé•·å®‰å›ä¹‹ä½ï¼Œè€Œå°ä¹‹ä»¥è†è…´ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå¤šèˆ‡ä¹‹é‡å™¨ï¼Œè€Œä¸åŠä»Šä»¤æœ‰åŠŸæ–¼åœ‹ï¼Œä¸€æ—¦å±±é™µå´©ï¼Œé•·å®‰å›ä½•ä»¥è‡ªè¨—æ–¼è¶™ï¼Ÿ è€è‡£ä»¥åª¼ç‚ºé•·å®‰å›ä¹‹è¨ˆçŸ­ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…ä»¥ç‚ºæ„›ä¹‹ä¸è‹¥ç‡•åã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè«¾ï¼Œæ£å›ä¹‹æ‰€ä½¿ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç‚ºé•·å®‰å›ç´„è»Šç™¾ä¹˜ï¼Œè³ªæ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šå…µä¹ƒå‡ºã€‚
In King Xiaocheng's first year, Qin attacked Zhao and captured three cities. The king of Zhao had just ascended the throne; the dowager queen held power. Qin launched urgent attacks against them. The Zhao court sought aid from Qi. Qi replied: 'Send the Lord of Chang'an as hostage, and we will dispatch troops.' The dowager queen refused. Her ministers strongly urged her to reconsider. The dowager queen declared to her attendants: 'Anyone who dares mention sending the Lord of Chang'an as hostage again will get my spittle in their face.' Left Tutor Zhuo Long requested an audience with the dowager queen, who received him in a towering rage. He entered, approached slowly, and took his seat. He apologized: 'This old minister's feet are diseased; I cannot walk quickly. It has been too long since I saw your majesty.' 'I privately excused myself from court, but I worried that your majesty might be ailing. Thus I wished to pay my respects.' The dowager queen replied: 'This old woman gets about by palanquin these days.' 'And is your appetite perhaps diminished?' 'I manage on thin gruel.' 'This old minister recently lost all appetite for food. I forced myself to walk three or four li each day. Gradually my appetite improved, bringing harmony to my body.' The dowager queen said: 'This old woman cannot manage that.' The dowager queen's angry expression softened slightly. The Left Tutor continued: 'This old minister's youngest son, Shuqi, is quite unworthy. As I grow feeble, I cherish him dearly. I humbly request that he be given a position among the black-robed guards to protect the royal palace. I risk death in making this plea.' The dowager queen replied: 'I respectfully agree. How old is he?' He answered: 'Fifteen years old. Though young, I wish to secure his position before I die and fill the grave.' The dowager queen asked: 'Do fathers also dote on their youngest sons?' He replied: 'Even more than women do.' The dowager queen laughed: 'Women are quite different indeed.' He replied: 'This old minister privately believes your majesty loves the Queen of Yan more than the Lord of Chang'an.' The dowager queen said: 'You are wrong. I do not love her as much as I love the Lord of Chang'an.' The Left Tutor said: 'When parents truly love their children, they plan far ahead for them. When your majesty sent the Queen of Yan away, you clutched her feet and wept, grieving over her distant journey.' Even after she left, you never stopped thinking of her. At sacrifices you prayed: 'Never let her return.' Was this not long-term planning to ensure her descendants would reign as kings in succession?' The dowager queen said: 'Yes.' The Left Tutor said: 'Now, looking back three generations to the present day, among the descendants of Zhao rulers who were enfeoffed as marquises, do any of their successors still hold their positions?' She replied: 'None.' She asked: 'Not just Zhaoâ€”do any of the other feudal lords' descendants still hold their positions?' She replied: 'This old woman has heard of none.' He explained: 'This happens because for those close in time, calamity strikes their own persons; for those more distant, it reaches their descendants. Could it be that the sons of rulers who are enfeoffed as marquises are somehow unworthy?' 'They hold honored positions without merit, receive rich stipends without labor, yet possess many precious treasures.' 'Now your majesty exalts the Lord of Chang'an's position and grants him fertile lands and many treasures, but does not give him the chance to earn merit for the state. When you pass away, how will the Lord of Chang'an secure his position in Zhao?' 'This old minister believes your majesty's planning for the Lord of Chang'an is shortsighted. Therefore, I submit that your love for him does not equal your love for the Queen of Yan.' The dowager queen said: 'Very well. I entrust you to handle this as you see fit.' Thus they equipped the Lord of Chang'an with a hundred chariots and sent him as hostage to Qi. Only then did Qi dispatch its troops.

Qi's Lord of Anping, Tian Dan, led Zhao forces in attacking Yan's Zhongyang and captured it. He then attacked Han's Zhuren and captured it. In the second year, Empress Huiwen passed away. Tian Dan was appointed chancellor.

In the fourth year, the king dreamed he wore a one-sided fur robe, rode a flying dragon toward heaven, but fell short and plummeted down, beholding mountains of gold and jade piled up. The next day, the king summoned the diviner Shi Gan to interpret the dream: 'Dreaming of wearing one-sided fur clothing signifies something incomplete.' 'Riding a flying dragon toward heaven but falling short signifies having appearance without substance.' 'Seeing mountains of gold and jade piled up signifies anxiety.'
