å¾Œä¸‰æ—¥ï¼ŒéŸ“æ°ä¸Šé»¨å®ˆé¦®äº­ä½¿è€…è‡³ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€ŒéŸ“ä¸èƒ½å®ˆä¸Šé»¨ï¼Œå…¥ä¹‹æ–¼ç§¦ã€‚ å…¶åæ°‘çš†å®‰ç‚ºè¶™ï¼Œä¸æ¬²ç‚ºç§¦ã€‚ æœ‰åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒï¼Œé¡˜å†æ‹œå…¥ä¹‹è¶™ï¼Œè²¡ç‹æ‰€ä»¥è³œåæ°‘ã€‚ã€ ç‹å¤§å–œï¼Œå¬å¹³é™½å›è±¹å‘Šä¹‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œé¦®äº­å…¥åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒï¼Œå—ä¹‹ä½•å¦‚ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè–äººç”šç¦ç„¡æ•…ä¹‹åˆ©ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œäººæ‡·å¾å¾·ï¼Œä½•è¬‚ç„¡æ•…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤«ç§¦è ¶é£ŸéŸ“æ°åœ°ï¼Œä¸­çµ•ä¸ä»¤ç›¸é€šï¼Œå›ºè‡ªä»¥ç‚ºåè€Œå—ä¸Šé»¨ä¹‹åœ°ä¹Ÿã€‚ éŸ“æ°æ‰€ä»¥ä¸å…¥æ–¼ç§¦è€…ï¼Œæ¬²å«å…¶ç¦æ–¼è¶™ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç§¦æœå…¶å‹è€Œè¶™å—å…¶åˆ©ï¼Œé›–å½Šå¤§ä¸èƒ½å¾—ä¹‹æ–¼å°å¼±ï¼Œå°å¼±é¡§èƒ½å¾—ä¹‹æ–¼å½Šå¤§ä¹ï¼Ÿ è±ˆå¯è¬‚éç„¡æ•…ä¹‹åˆ©å“‰ï¼ ä¸”å¤«ç§¦ä»¥ç‰›ç”°ä¹‹æ°´é€šç³§è ¶é£Ÿï¼Œä¸Šä¹˜å€æˆ°è€…ï¼Œè£‚ä¸Šåœ‹ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå…¶æ”¿è¡Œï¼Œä¸å¯èˆ‡ç‚ºé›£ï¼Œå¿…å‹¿å—ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šç™¼ç™¾è¬ä¹‹è»è€Œæ”»ï¼Œè¸°å¹´æ­·æ­²æœªå¾—ä¸€åŸä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šä»¥åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒå¹£å¾åœ‹ï¼Œæ­¤å¤§åˆ©ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€
Three days later, an envoy from Han's governor of Shangdang, Feng Ting, arrived and said: 'Han cannot hold Shangdang and will cede it to Qin.' 'Its officials and people would all prefer to become Zhao subjects; they do not wish to become Qin subjects.' 'There are seventeen cities and towns. We humbly offer them to Zhao with repeated bows, for your majesty to bestow rewards on the officials and people as you see fit.' The king was overjoyed and summoned Zhao Bao, Lord of Pingyang, to tell him: 'Feng Ting is offering seventeen cities and towns. What do you think of accepting them?' He replied: 'The sages greatly fear benefits that come without cause.' The king said: 'People are drawn to my benevolence. How can this be called unearned?' He replied: 'Qin has been nibbling away at Han's territory like a silkworm, cutting off connections in the middle. They fully expect to sit back and receive Shangdang's lands without effort.' 'The reason Han won't cede to Qin is that they want to shift their disaster onto Zhao.' 'Qin bears all the effort while Zhao reaps the benefit. Even the strong cannot seize from the weakâ€”what makes you think the weak can seize from the strong?' 'How can this not be called a benefit without cause!' 'Moreover, Qin uses the Nitian waterway to transport grain while steadily encroaching. Their elite troops fight with double efficiency, carving up the territories of superior states. Their administration succeeds; one cannot challenge them. You must not accept.' The king said: 'If we dispatch a million-man army to attack, it would take years and we still might not capture a single city.' 'Now seventeen cities and towns enrich our stateâ€”this is tremendous benefit.'

è¶™è±¹å‡ºï¼Œç‹å¬å¹³åŸå›èˆ‡è¶™ç¦¹è€Œå‘Šä¹‹ã€‚ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œç™¼ç™¾è¬ä¹‹è»è€Œæ”»ï¼Œè¸°æ­²æœªå¾—ä¸€åŸï¼Œä»Šåå—åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒï¼Œæ­¤å¤§åˆ©ï¼Œä¸å¯å¤±ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå–„ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒä»¤è¶™å‹å—åœ°ï¼Œå‘Šé¦®äº­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•åœ‹ä½¿è€…è‡£å‹ï¼Œæ•åœ‹å›ä½¿å‹è‡´å‘½ï¼Œä»¥è¬æˆ¶éƒ½ä¸‰å°å¤ªå®ˆï¼Œåƒæˆ¶éƒ½ä¸‰å°ç¸£ä»¤ï¼Œçš†ä¸–ä¸–ç‚ºä¾¯ï¼Œåæ°‘çš†ç›Šçˆµä¸‰ç´šï¼Œåæ°‘èƒ½ç›¸å®‰ï¼Œçš†è³œä¹‹å…­é‡‘ã€‚ã€ é¦®äº­å‚æ¶•ä¸è¦‹ä½¿è€…ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾ä¸è™•ä¸‰ä¸ç¾©ä¹Ÿï¼šç‚ºä¸»å®ˆåœ°ï¼Œä¸èƒ½æ­»å›ºï¼Œä¸ç¾©ä¸€çŸ£ï¼› å…¥ä¹‹ç§¦ï¼Œä¸è½ä¸»ä»¤ï¼Œä¸ç¾©äºŒçŸ£ï¼› è³£ä¸»åœ°è€Œé£Ÿä¹‹ï¼Œä¸ç¾©ä¸‰çŸ£ã€‚ã€ è¶™é‚ç™¼å…µå–ä¸Šé»¨ã€‚ å»‰é —å°‡è»è»é•·å¹³ã€‚
Zhao Bao departed. The king summoned the Lord of Pingyuan and Zhao Yu to inform them. They replied: 'If we dispatch a million-man army to attack, it would take over a year and we still might not capture one city. Now we receive seventeen cities and towns without effortâ€”this is tremendous benefit. We cannot let it slip away.' The king said: 'Excellent.' Thus he ordered Zhao Sheng to accept the territory and told Feng Ting: 'Our humble state's envoy, your servant Zhao Sheng. Our lord has sent me to convey: Cities of ten thousand households shall be made into three commanderies with governors; cities of thousand households into three counties with magistrates. All shall be marquises for generations. Officials and people shall all advance three ranks. Those officials and people who live in harmony shall each receive six pieces of gold.' Feng Ting wept and refused to see the envoy, declaring: 'I will not commit three acts of unrighteousness. As guardian of my lord's territory, I could not die defending itâ€”that is the first unrighteousness;' 'To cede it to Qin without obeying my lord's commandâ€”that is the second unrighteousness;' 'To sell my lord's territory for personal gainâ€”that is the third unrighteousness.' Zhao thus sent troops to seize Shangdang. Lian Po commanded the army stationed at Changping.

ä¸ƒï¼ˆå¹´ï¼‰ï¼»æœˆï¼½ï¼Œå»‰é —å…è€Œè¶™æ‹¬ä»£å°‡ã€‚ ç§¦äººåœè¶™æ‹¬ï¼Œè¶™æ‹¬ä»¥è»é™ï¼Œå’å››åé¤˜è¬çš†é˜¬ä¹‹ã€‚ ç‹æ‚”ä¸è½è¶™è±¹ä¹‹è¨ˆï¼Œæ•…æœ‰é•·å¹³ä¹‹ç¦ç„‰ã€‚
In the seventh month, Lian Po was relieved of command and Zhao Kuo took his place. The Qin surrounded Zhao Kuo. Zhao Kuo surrendered his entire army, and over 400,000 soldiers were buried alive. The king bitterly regretted ignoring Zhao Bao's counsel, thus bringing about the Changping catastrophe.

The king returned home but refused to heed Qin. Qin then besieged Handan. The magistrate of Wuyuanâ€”Fu Bao, Wang Rong, and Su Sheâ€”led Yan forces in rebellion within Yan territory. Zhao granted Lingqiu as fief to Chu's chancellor, the Lord of Chunshen.
103
å…«å¹´ï¼Œå¹³åŸå›å¦‚æ¥šè«‹æ•‘ã€‚ é‚„ï¼Œæ¥šä¾†æ•‘ï¼ŒåŠé­å…¬å­ç„¡å¿Œäº¦ä¾†æ•‘ï¼Œç§¦åœé‚¯é„²ä¹ƒè§£ã€‚
In the eighth year, the Lord of Pingyuan traveled to Chu to seek assistance. Upon his return, Chu sent troops to aid Zhao. Wei's Prince Wuji also arrived with reinforcements. Qin's siege of Handan was finally broken.
104
åå¹´ï¼Œç‡•æ”»æ˜Œå£¯ï¼Œäº”æœˆæ‹”ä¹‹ã€‚ è¶™å°‡æ¨‚ä¹˜ã€æ…¶èˆæ”»ç§¦ä¿¡æ¢è»ï¼Œç ´ä¹‹ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ­»ã€‚ è€Œç§¦æ”»è¥¿å‘¨ï¼Œæ‹”ä¹‹ã€‚ å¾’çˆ¶ç¥ºå‡ºã€‚ åä¸€å¹´ï¼ŒåŸå…ƒæ°ï¼Œç¸£ä¸ŠåŸã€‚ æ­¦é™½å›é„­å®‰å¹³æ­»ï¼Œæ”¶å…¶åœ°ã€‚ åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œé‚¯é„²å»¥ç‡’ã€‚ åå››å¹´ï¼Œå¹³åŸå›è¶™å‹æ­»ã€‚
In the tenth year, Yan attacked Changzhuang and captured it by the fifth month. Zhao generals Yue Cheng and Qing She attacked and defeated Qin's Xinliang army. The crown prince died. Meanwhile, Qin attacked and captured Western Zhou. Tu Fuqi departed. In the eleventh year, they fortified Yuanshi with city walls and established Shangyuan as a county. The Lord of Wuyang, Zheng Anping, died and his territory was reclaimed. In the twelfth year, Handan's granaries burned down. In the fourteenth year, the Lord of Pingyuan, Zhao Sheng, passed away.
105
åäº”å¹´ï¼Œä»¥å°‰æ–‡å°ç›¸åœ‹å»‰é —ç‚ºä¿¡å¹³å›ã€‚ ç‡•ç‹ä»¤ä¸ç›¸æ —è…¹ç´„é©¤ï¼Œä»¥äº”ç™¾é‡‘ç‚ºè¶™ç‹é…’ï¼Œé‚„æ­¸ï¼Œå ±ç‡•ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ°å£¯è€…çš†æ­»é•·å¹³ï¼Œå…¶å­¤æœªå£¯ï¼Œå¯ä¼ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç‹å¬æ˜Œåœ‹å›æ¨‚é–’è€Œå•ä¹‹ã€‚ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™ï¼Œå››æˆ°ä¹‹åœ‹ä¹Ÿï¼Œå…¶æ°‘ç¿’å…µï¼Œä¼ä¹‹ä¸å¯ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾ä»¥çœ¾ä¼å¯¡ï¼ŒäºŒè€Œä¼ä¸€ï¼Œå¯ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å³ä»¥äº”è€Œä¼ä¸€ï¼Œå¯ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ã€‚ã€ ç‡•ç‹å¤§æ€’ã€‚ ç¾¤è‡£çš†ä»¥ç‚ºå¯ã€‚ ç‡•å’èµ·äºŒè»ï¼Œè»ŠäºŒåƒä¹˜ï¼Œæ —è…¹å°‡è€Œæ”»é„—ï¼Œå¿ç§¦å°‡è€Œæ”»ä»£ã€‚ å»‰é —ç‚ºè¶™å°‡ï¼Œç ´æ®ºæ —è…¹ï¼Œè™œå¿ç§¦ã€æ¨‚é–’ã€‚
In the fifteenth year, he granted Chancellor Lian Po the title Lord of Xinping along with the Yuwen estate. The King of Yan ordered Chancellor Li Fu to negotiate an alliance with Zhao, offering five hundred pieces of gold to toast the King of Zhao. Upon returning home, he reported to the King of Yan: 'Zhao's fighting men all perished at Changping; their orphans are still children. Now is the time to attack.' The king summoned Yue Xian, Lord of Changguo, and consulted him. He replied: 'Zhao is a nation hardened by constant warfare on four borders; its people are battle-tested. It would be folly to attack them.' The king said: 'What if I attack with superior numbersâ€”two against one?' He replied: 'Still not advisable.' The king said: 'What if I attack with five to one odds?' He replied: 'Even then, it would not be wise.' The King of Yan flew into a rage. All his ministers urged him to proceed. Yan mobilized two armies with two thousand chariots. Li Fu led the attack on Xiang; Qing Qin commanded the assault on Dai. Lian Po, commanding Zhao's forces, defeated and slew Li Fu, taking Qing Qin and Yue Xian prisoner.
106
åå…­å¹´ï¼Œå»‰é —åœç‡•ã€‚ ä»¥æ¨‚ä¹˜ç‚ºæ­¦è¥„å›ã€‚ åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œå‡ç›¸å¤§å°‡æ­¦è¥„å›æ”»ç‡•ï¼Œåœå…¶åœ‹ã€‚ åå…«å¹´ï¼Œå»¶é™µéˆç‡å¸«å¾ç›¸åœ‹ä¿¡å¹³å›åŠ©é­æ”»ç‡•ã€‚ ç§¦æ‹”æˆ‘æ¦†æ¬¡ä¸‰åä¸ƒåŸã€‚ åä¹å¹´ï¼Œè¶™èˆ‡ç‡•æ˜“åœŸï¼šä»¥é¾å…Œã€æ±¾é–€ã€è‡¨æ¨‚èˆ‡ç‡•ï¼› ç‡•ä»¥è‘›ã€æ­¦é™½ã€å¹³èˆ’èˆ‡è¶™ã€‚
In the sixteenth year, Lian Po laid siege to Yan. He granted Yue Cheng the title Lord of Wuxiang. In the seventeenth year, the acting chancellor and supreme commander Lord of Wuxiang attacked Yan and besieged its capital. In the eighteenth year, Yanling Gou led troops under Chancellor Lord of Xinping to assist Wei's attack on Yan. Qin captured thirty-seven of our cities at Yuci. In the nineteenth year, Zhao and Yan exchanged territories: Zhao ceded Longdui, Fenmen, and Linle to Yan; Yan ceded Ge, Wuyang, and Pingshu to Zhao.
107
äºŒåå¹´ï¼Œç§¦ç‹æ”¿åˆç«‹ã€‚ ç§¦æ‹”æˆ‘æ™‰é™½ã€‚
In the twentieth year, Qin King Zheng ascended the throne for the first time. Qin captured our Jinyang.
108
äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œå­æˆç‹å’ã€‚ å»‰é —å°‡ï¼Œæ”»ç¹é™½ï¼Œå–ä¹‹ã€‚ ä½¿æ¨‚ä¹˜ä»£ä¹‹ï¼Œå»‰é —æ”»æ¨‚ä¹˜ï¼Œæ¨‚ä¹˜èµ°ï¼Œå»‰é —äº¡å…¥é­ã€‚ å­åƒç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ‚¼è¥„ç‹ã€‚
In the twenty-first year, King Xiaocheng passed away. Lian Po commanded the attack on Fanyang and captured it. They sent Yue Cheng to replace him. Lian Po attacked Yue Cheng, who fled. Lian Po then fled to Wei. Zi Yan ascended the throne as King Daoxiang.
109
æ‚¼è¥„ç‹å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œå¤§å‚™é­ã€‚ æ¬²é€šå¹³é‚‘ã€ä¸­ç‰Ÿä¹‹é“ï¼Œä¸æˆã€‚
In King Daoxiang's first year, he made extensive preparations against Wei. He attempted to open a road from Pingyi to Zhongmu but failed.
110
äºŒå¹´ï¼Œæç‰§å°‡ï¼Œæ”»ç‡•ï¼Œæ‹”æ­¦é‚ã€æ–¹åŸã€‚ ç§¦å¬æ˜¥å¹³å›ï¼Œå› è€Œç•™ä¹‹ã€‚ æ³„éˆç‚ºä¹‹è¬‚æ–‡ä¿¡ä¾¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜¥å¹³å›è€…ï¼Œè¶™ç‹ç”šæ„›ä¹‹è€Œéƒä¸­ä¹‹ï¼Œæ•…ç›¸èˆ‡è¬€æ›°ã€æ˜¥å¹³å›å…¥ç§¦ï¼Œç§¦å¿…ç•™ä¹‹ã€ï¼Œæ•…ç›¸èˆ‡è¬€è€Œå…§ä¹‹ç§¦ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå›ç•™ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯çµ•è¶™è€Œéƒä¸­ä¹‹è¨ˆä¸­ä¹Ÿã€‚ å›ä¸å¦‚é£æ˜¥å¹³å›è€Œç•™å¹³éƒ½ã€‚ æ˜¥å¹³å›è€…è¨€è¡Œä¿¡æ–¼ç‹ï¼Œç‹å¿…åšå‰²è¶™è€Œè´–å¹³éƒ½ã€‚ã€ æ–‡ä¿¡ä¾¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œå–„ã€‚ã€ å› é£ä¹‹ã€‚ åŸéŸ“çš‹ã€‚
In the second year, Li Mu commanded the attack on Yan and captured Wushui and Fangcheng. Qin summoned the Lord of Chunping and detained him as hostage. Xie Gou said to the Lord of Wenxin on his behalf: 'The Lord of Chunping is deeply cherished by the King of Zhao and serves among his attendants. They plotted together, saying: "If the Lord of Chunping enters Qin, Qin will certainly detain him." Thus they conspired to send him into Qin.' 'If you detain him now, you will alienate Zhao and play right into the attendants' scheme.' 'You would do better to release the Lord of Chunping and detain Pingdu instead.' 'The Lord of Chunping has the king's complete trust in word and deed. The king will surely cede substantial Zhao territory to ransom Pingdu.' The Lord of Wenxin replied: 'Excellent.' Thus he released him. He built fortifications at Hanga.
111
ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œé¾ç…–å°‡ï¼Œæ”»ç‡•ï¼Œç¦½å…¶å°‡åŠ‡è¾›ã€‚ å››å¹´ï¼Œé¾ç…–å°‡è¶™ã€æ¥šã€é­ã€ç‡•ä¹‹éŠ³å¸«ï¼Œæ”»ç§¦è•ï¼Œä¸æ‹”ï¼› ç§»æ”»é½Šï¼Œå–é¥’å®‰ã€‚ äº”å¹´ï¼Œå‚…æŠµå°‡ï¼Œå±…å¹³é‚‘ï¼› æ…¶èˆå°‡æ±é™½æ²³å¤–å¸«ï¼Œå®ˆæ²³æ¢ã€‚ å…­å¹´ï¼Œå°é•·å®‰å›ä»¥é¥’ã€‚ é­èˆ‡è¶™é„´ã€‚
In the third year, Pang Juan commanded the attack on Yan and captured their general Ju Xin. In the fourth year, Pang Juan led elite forces from Zhao, Chu, Wei, and Yan in attacking Qin's Zhui, but failed to capture it; then shifted to attack Qi and captured Rao'an. In the fifth year, Fu Di commanded and was stationed at Pingyi; Qing She commanded the Dongyang troops beyond the river, defending the river crossing. In the sixth year, he granted Rao as fief to the Lord of Chang'an. Wei met with Zhao at Ye.
112
ä¹å¹´ï¼Œè¶™æ”»ç‡•ï¼Œå–è²ã€é™½åŸã€‚ å…µæœªç½·ï¼Œç§¦æ”»é„´ï¼Œæ‹”ä¹‹ã€‚ æ‚¼è¥„ç‹å’ï¼Œå­å¹½ç¹†ç‹é·ç«‹ã€‚
In the ninth year, Zhao attacked Yan and captured Li and Yangcheng. Before the troops could be disbanded, Qin attacked Ye and captured it. King Daoxiang died. His son ascended the throne as King Youmiu.
113
å¹½ç¹†ç‹é·å…ƒå¹´ï¼ŒåŸæŸäººã€‚ äºŒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ”»æ­¦åŸï¼Œæ‰ˆè¼’ç‡å¸«æ•‘ä¹‹ï¼Œè»æ•—ï¼Œæ­»ç„‰ã€‚
In King Youmiu's first year, fortifications were built at Baoren. In the second year, Qin attacked Wucheng. Hu Zhe led troops to its rescue, but the army was defeated and he died in battle.
114
ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ”»èµ¤éº—ã€å®œå®‰ï¼Œæç‰§ç‡å¸«èˆ‡æˆ°è‚¥ä¸‹ï¼Œå»ä¹‹ã€‚ å°ç‰§ç‚ºæ­¦å®‰å›ã€‚ å››å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ”»ç•ªå¾ï¼Œæç‰§èˆ‡ä¹‹æˆ°ï¼Œå»ä¹‹ã€‚
In the third year, Qin attacked Chilli and Yian. Li Mu led troops to fight them below Fei and drove them back. Mu was granted the title Lord of Wuan. In the fourth year, Qin attacked Fanwu. Li Mu fought them and drove them back.
115
äº”å¹´ï¼Œä»£åœ°å¤§å‹•ï¼Œè‡ªæ¨‚å¾ä»¥è¥¿ï¼ŒåŒ—è‡³å¹³é™°ï¼Œè‡ºå±‹å¢»å£å¤ªåŠå£ï¼Œåœ°å¼æ±è¥¿ç™¾ä¸‰åæ­¥ã€‚ å…­å¹´ï¼Œå¤§é¥‘ï¼Œæ°‘è¨›è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™ç‚ºè™Ÿï¼Œç§¦ç‚ºç¬‘ã€‚ ä»¥ç‚ºä¸ä¿¡ï¼Œè¦–åœ°ä¹‹ç”Ÿæ¯›ã€‚ã€
In the fifth year, a massive earthquake struck Dai territory. From west of Le Xu north to Pingyin, terraces, houses, and walls were more than half destroyed. The earth split apart for one hundred thirty paces east to west. In the sixth year, a great famine struck. The people spread rumors saying: 'Zhao calls out, Qin laughs.' 'To test if it's not credible, look for hair growing on the ground.'
116
ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦äººæ”»è¶™ï¼Œè¶™å¤§å°‡æç‰§ã€å°‡è»å¸é¦¬å°šå°‡ï¼Œæ“Šä¹‹ã€‚ æç‰§èª…ï¼Œå¸é¦¬å°šå…ï¼Œè¶™æ€±åŠé½Šå°‡é¡èšä»£ä¹‹ã€‚ è¶™æ€±è»ç ´ï¼Œé¡èšäº¡å»ã€‚ ä»¥ç‹é·é™ã€‚
In the seventh year, Qin attacked Zhao. Zhao's supreme commander Li Mu and general Sima Shang led the counterattack. Li Mu was executed and Sima Shang dismissed. Zhao Cong and Qi's general Yan Ju took their places. Zhao Cong's army was routed and Yan Ju fled. King Qian surrendered to Qin.
117
å…«å¹´åæœˆï¼Œé‚¯é„²ç‚ºç§¦ã€‚
In the tenth month of the eighth year, Handan fell to Qin.
118
å¤ªå²å…¬æ›°ã€‚ å¾èé¦®ç‹å­«æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™ç‹é·ï¼Œå…¶æ¯å€¡ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¬–æ–¼æ‚¼è¥„ç‹ã€‚ æ‚¼è¥„ç‹å»¢é©å­å˜‰è€Œç«‹é·ã€‚ é·ç´ ç„¡è¡Œï¼Œä¿¡è®’ï¼Œæ•…èª…å…¶è‰¯å°‡æç‰§ï¼Œç”¨éƒ­é–‹ã€‚ã€ è±ˆä¸ç¹†å“‰ï¼ ç§¦æ—¢è™œé·ï¼Œè¶™ä¹‹äº¡å¤§å¤«å…±ç«‹å˜‰ç‚ºç‹ï¼Œç‹ä»£å…­æ­²ï¼Œç§¦é€²å…µç ´å˜‰ï¼Œé‚æ»…è¶™ä»¥ç‚ºéƒ¡ã€‚
The Grand Historian remarks: I heard Feng Wangsun say: 'King Qian of Zhao's mother was a singing girl who found favor with King Daoxiang.' King Daoxiang deposed his legitimate heir Jia and installed Qian on the throne. Qian was habitually immoral and gullible to slanderers. Thus he executed his fine general Li Mu and employed the treacherous Guo Kai.' How tragic a mistake! After Qin captured Qian, Zhao's exiled nobles united to establish Jia as king. He ruled in Dai for six years, but Qin advanced its armies, defeated Jia, and thus extinguished Zhao, reducing it to a mere commandery.
